(3) Minimum yard adjacent to public street: a. From major thoroughfares: 250 feet. b. From minor thoroughfares: 150 feet. c. From collector streets: 100 feet. d. From other streets: 100 feet. (4) Minimum yard adjacent to interior driveways: Ten feet. (5) Interior side yard: 7.5 feet. (6) Minimum rear yard: 7.5 feet. (7) Maximum height of buildings: No building shall exceed 35 feet in height. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-432), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-782. - Transitional buffer zone requirement. Where a lot in the MHP (Mobile Home Park) District is used for attached single-family dwellings and adjoins the boundary of any property which is zoned R (Single-Family Residential) District, except single-family attached developments, a transitional buffer zone not less than 50 feet in width shall be provided and maintained in a natural state. Said transitional buffer zone shall not be paved and shall not be used for parking, loading, storage or any other use, except where necessary to grade or modify a portion of the transitional buffer zone for the installation of utilities necessitated by the development. Water detention ponds shall not be located within transitional buffer zones. No trees, other than dead or diseased trees, shall be removed from said transitional buffer zone, but additional trees and plant material may be added to the transitional buffer zone. In addition, a screening fence not less than six feet in height shall be erected and maintained either along the property line or within the transitional buffer zone separating the use from the adjoining single-family residential district. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-433), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-783. - Mobile home park design requirements. The following design requirements shall apply to all mobile home parks: (1) Density. The maximum density shall not exceed eight mobile home units per acre. Only 50 percent of any portion of the land within a mobile home park that is located within a floodplain may be included for the purpose of density determination. (2) Street access requirements. A mobile home park shall abut upon a major thoroughfare, a minor thoroughfare, or a local access road paralleling a freeway or railroad right-of-way. It shall have a minimum of 400 feet frontage in order to provide adequate and safe ingress and egress from the abutting road to the mobile home park. It shall have ingress and ingress only from the above roads. The minimum distance between curb cuts shall be 30 feet. The entrance or exit road to the development shall have a minimum right-of-way width of 60 feet with a minimum pavement width of 28 feet. The entrance or exit road shall have a turning radius of at least 30 feet and the road shall extend for at least 100 feet into the mobile home park with no parking and with no ingress to or egress from any individual mobile home lot. (3) Mobile home lots. Each mobile home shall be located on a mobile home lot. Each lot shall conform to the following requirements: a. Street frontage. Each mobile home lot shall front on an interior driveway having a pavement width of not less than 20 feet, or more, dependent upon the function and classification of the interior driveway as set forth in the "Mobile Home Court Development Guide," FHA G4200.7, published January, 1970, which is adopted by reference and made a part of this chapter. b. Mobile home lot width and depth. Each lot shall be not less than 50 feet wide and 80 feet deep. c. Mobile home stand. A mobile home stand shall be located on each lot for the placement of the mobile home and it appurtenant structures and for the tie-down of the mobile home. The stand shall provide for the retention of the mobile home on the lot in a stable condition and in a satisfactory relationship to its surroundings. Acceptable provisions for hurricane anchorage for each mobile home shall be provided. d. Yard requirements. Each mobile home lot shall have side and rear yards with a minimum width or depth of 7.5 feet and front yards with a minimum depth of ten feet, but in no case shall the distance between mobile home stands on opposite sides of the street be less than 40 feet. No structural addition to a mobile home shall be built within a required yard. (4) Recreation area. One acre of land shall be set aside and developed within the mobile home park for open space and recreation purposes for each 50 lots. The minimum size of a single open space and recreation area shall be 10,000 square feet. Not more than 50 percent of the land reserved for open space and recreation purposes shall be located within a floodplain. (5) Automobile parking spaces. At least two automobile parking spaces shall be provided for each mobile home lot. At least one such space shall be provided on each mobile home lot. The second required space may be provided on the mobile home lot, in on-street parking lanes or bays, or in an off-street parking lot conveniently located to the mobile home it serves. (6) Boundary setbacks. All mobile homes within a mobile home park shall be set back not less than 50 feet from the boundary line of the mobile home park, except that where the boundary of the mobile home park adjoins a residential district, said setback shall be not less than 100 feet. (7) Design standards. All mobile home parks shall conform to the standards and requirements of "Mobile Home Court Development Guide," U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development, FHA G4200.7, published January 1970, which by this reference is made a part of this chapter. All mobile home parks shall also conform to all of the requirements of chapter 14, article VII. (8) Site construction and development. No site construction or development shall be undertaken and no development or building permits shall be issued until a preliminary subdivision plat shall have been approved for the mobile home park pursuant to the requirements of chapter 14. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-434), 9-23-2014) Secs. 27-784—27-804. - Reserved. DIVISION 22. - TND (TRADITIONAL NEIGHBORHOOD DEVELOPMENT) DISTRICT
Sec. 27-805. - Repealer. Except as provided in section 27-50, the TND regulations of this division are repealed. No application or amendment to the official zoning map shall be filed with the planning director, initiated by official action of the planning commission, or considered by the city council if such amendment or application seeks to have any lot in the City zoned TND. Effective April 27, 2004, the TND regulations set forth in this division remain codified solely for the purpose of complying with the requirements of section 27-50. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-460), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-806. - Scope of provisions. The provisions contained within this division are the regulations of the TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development) District. This division establishes the procedures and the criteria that the city council shall utilize in making a decision on any application to amend the official zoning map so as to change any parcel of land to the TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development) District zoning classification. A Traditional Neighborhood Development District shall not be deemed to be a subdivision within the meaning of the land development code. Except to the extent referenced in this division, the requirements of chapter 14, article VII, shall not be applied to a TND district application. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-461), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-807. - Statement of purpose and intent. The purpose and intent of the city council in establishing the TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development) District is to establish a zoning district classification by which the city may permit a variety in type, design, and arrangement of residential structures and enable the coordination of project characteristics with features of a particular site in a manner consistent with the public health, safety, and general welfare. Appropriate areas for the location of Traditional Neighborhood Development Districts include tracts of land of sufficient size for the creation of traditional neighborhood development communities. Appropriate areas for the location of Traditional Neighborhood Development Districts further include tracts of land where there is the presence of waterways, floodplains, wetlands, natural and archaeological resources, or historic building or site, which areas do not lend themselves to development under standard subdivision requirements as are provided in chapter 14, article VII. The Traditional Neighborhood Development District is established so as to permit reasonable residential development of such properties while at the same time protecting and preserving important features of the natural and built environment and to permit innovative design of new communities, including traditional neighborhood development communities. TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development) Districts are intended to allow for innovations and special features in site development, including the location of structures, conservation of natural land features, conservation of energy and efficient utilization of open space. The TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development) District is further intended to accomplish public objectives as follows: (1) To establish a zoning district classification within which traditional neighborhood development communities can be established within the city; (2) To provide for residential development of parcels of land where a portion of the property is to remain undisturbed or in open space in perpetuity so as to preserve sensitive natural areas and to permit innovative community planning while realizing reasonable intensity of development on such parcels by clustering new dwellings on the most suitable building areas of such parcels of land; (3) To ensure that infill development authorized pursuant to these district regulations is compatible with the density and the character of surrounding uses; and (4) To ensure that basic services are available to serve the recreational, educational and social needs of the neighborhood. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-462), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-808. - Procedures. The following requirements shall apply to each application for change of the official zoning map to the Traditional Neighborhood Development District classification: (1) Program for unified control. Each applicant for the Traditional Neighborhood Development zoning classification shall provide a legal mechanism for unified control of the entire parcel. During the development process, more than one builder may participate in the development of the approved plan so long as each parcel of land remains subject to all of the terms and conditions of the plan approved by the city council for the property as a whole. (2) Application requirements. All applications for the TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development) District designation shall be for a tract of land having a lot area of not less than ten acres and not more than 100 acres. The proposed use may consist of any authorized use or combination of authorized uses contained in section 27-811. (3) Procedures same as article V, division 2 of this chapter. Each application for TND district classification shall be filed with the planning department and shall be reviewed and public hearings conducted with public notice provided and decisions made all as is required for applications to amend the official zoning map pursuant to article V, division 2 of this chapter and with the additional standards and factors contained in section 27-809. (4) Plans required. In addition to all of the information and materials required as a part of an application to amend the official zoning map in article V, division 2, of this chapter, each applicant for TND shall submit a survey of the existing topography of the site at intervals of not less than five feet, a proposed site plan, and a preliminary grading plan for the site. The site plan shall be prepared, signed and sealed by an architect, landscape architect or engineer licensed in the state and shall contain the following information: a. Size of each lot proposed. b. Buildable area of each lot. c. Development density. d. Housing types. e. Spacing between buildings. f. Location of accessory buildings and uses. g. Sidewalk requirements. h. Street requirements. i. Parking requirements, including a written justification when the applicant is simultaneously applying, pursuant to section 27-821, for approval of a reduction in the number of parking spaces otherwise required by section 27-817. j. Landscaping requirements. k. Open space areas to be held in joint ownership common ownership or control in perpetuity. l. Location and amount of accessory commercial space. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-463), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-809. - Additional standards and factors to be considered. The city may approve or may approve with modifications or conditions an application for Traditional Neighborhood Development District designation if, in addition to meeting all of the criteria contained in article V, division 2, of this chapter, the applicant meets each of the following standards: (1) That the proposed Traditional Neighborhood Development District accomplishes, by the use of permitted flexibility and variation in design, a development that has a greater net benefit to the city than that resulting from development under the land subdivision regulations. Net benefit to the city may be demonstrated by one or more of the following factors: a. Creation of a community of compact scale and design which encourages pedestrian circulation; b. Creation of a design in which the village center or other authorized accessory commercial use is so located as to be accessible to residents of the community within a five-minute walk. c. Interconnected usable open space; d. Recreation facilities; e. Other public facilities; f. Conservation of natural, archaeological, or historic resources; g. Aesthetic features and harmonious design; or h. Energy efficient site design or building features. (2) That the Traditional Neighborhood Development District results in no greater burden on present and projected public services and utilities than would result from subdivision development and that the Traditional Neighborhood Development District will be served by adequate facilities including public streets, public fire protection, and public and private utilities. (3) That the front yard setback of buildings along any existing street is consistent with the setback of buildings on adjoining properties. (4) That the buffer surrounding all side and rear yards is equal in depth to the required rear yard of adjoining districts. (5) That at least one major circulation point is functionally connected to an existing public street. (6) That open space within the Traditional Neighborhood Development District is an integrated part of the project rather than an isolated element of the project. (7) That all public streets serving the development, both existing and proposed, are suitable in design and adequate to carry the anticipated traffic within the proposed project and in the vicinity of the proposed project. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-464), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-810. - Design and development standards. The following design and development standards shall apply to each Traditional Neighborhood Development District hereafter established by the city council: (1) Density. The density of the proposed development shall be as approved by the city council and shall be consistent with the comprehensive plan and with the surrounding area. The density of each Traditional Neighborhood Development District shall be established by the city council at the time of approval of any such application. (2) Public streets required. All streets within Traditional Neighborhood Development Districts shall be public streets and the design and construction of said streets shall comply in all respects with the requirements of chapter 14, this chapter, and any other applicable provision of the Code. (3) Sidewalk requirements. Five-foot sidewalks with a four-foot street tree planting zone between the sidewalk and the back of curb shall be provided on each street contained within any Traditional Neighborhood Development District. (4) Maintenance and protection of land held in common. Each applicant shall present as a part of the application for the TND zoning designation a legal mechanism under which all land to be held in common and used for open space purposes shall be protected in perpetuity. Such legal mechanism may include deed restrictions, homeowner associations, common areas held in common ownership or control, or any other legal mechanism, provided that said legal mechanism shall be approved by the community development department as assuring each of the following mandatory requirements: a. That all land held in common shall remain undivided and shall not be subdivided or developed in perpetuity; b. That all subsequent property owners in perpetuity within said Traditional Neighborhood Development District be placed on notice of this development restriction through the deed records of the superior court of the county; c. That all land held in common will be properly maintained and insured with no liability or maintenance responsibilities accruing to the city; d. That a legal mechanism exists for notice of deficiencies in maintenance of the land held in common, correction of these deficiencies, and assessment and liens against the properties for the cost of the correction of these deficiencies by a third party or the city; e. That the legal mechanism be created and implemented prior to the sale of any individual properties within the Traditional Neighborhood Development District; and f. That all requirements of the legal mechanism chosen by the applicant and approved by the community development department shall be specified on the final plan and recorded with the clerk of the superior court of the county. (5) Homeowners' association. When an applicant for a Traditional Neighborhood Development District chooses to utilize a homeowners' association in order to comply with the requirements of subsection (4) of this section, the applicant, in addition to meeting all of said requirements, shall provide for all of the following: a. Mandatory and automatic membership in the homeowners' association as a requirement of dwelling unit ownership; b. All owners shall have equal access and right of use to all common and shared facilities; c. A fair and uniform method of assessment for dues, maintenance and related costs; d. Where appropriate, party wall maintenance and restoration in the event of damage or destruction; e. Perpetual and continued maintenance of land held in common and liability through the use of liens or other means in the case of default; and f. That all required covenants, declarations and restrictions shall be filed with the clerk of the superior court of the county. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-465), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-811. - Principal uses and principal structures. The following are the principal uses of land and structures which are authorized in the TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development) District: (1) Dwelling, single-family attached. (2) Dwelling, single-family detached. (3) Dwelling, three-family. (4) Dwelling, two-family. (5) Dwellings, multifamily. (6) Personal care home, group. (7) Child caring institution, group. (8) Open space and public space. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-466), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-812. - Accessory uses and accessory structures. The following are the accessory uses of land and structures which are authorized in the TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development) District: (1) Accessory commercial uses, subject to the following requirements: a. Such use shall be limited to uses which are permissible within the NS district (see division 29 of this article); b. All accessory commercial uses shall be located within the interior of any TND District and shall not be visible from any public street outside the boundaries of such TND District or from any dwelling located outside the boundaries of such TND District; c. Accessory commercial use shall not exceed 25 percent of the gross residential floor space of the total development, and in no case shall total commercial use exceed 100,000 square feet, and no individual building shall exceed 50,000 square feet in total floor area; d. Within multifamily TND development, accessory commercial use may be located in freestanding buildings or in the ground floor level of multifamily dwellings; e. All accessory commercial space shall be concentrated within a designated area within any TND District; and f. Accessory commercial space shall be constructed concurrently with or after the construction of the dwelling units to which it is accessory, and no certificate of occupancy for such accessory commercial space shall be issued until certificates of occupancy have been issued for at least 50 percent of the dwelling units to be constructed within said development. (2) Accessory uses and structures incidental to any authorized use; (3) Recreation facilities including swimming pools, tennis courts, outdoor play areas, bikeways, walking trails, picnic pavilions, clubhouses, and similar recreation facilities designed for and used principally by the residents of the TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development) District; (4) Signs for accessory commercial use in accordance with the provisions of chapter 21 and this chapter. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-467), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-813. - Special permits. The following uses are allowed by special permits of the type indicated below: (1) Special administrative permit from the community development department director: a. Home occupation involving no customer contact and no employee other than a person residing on the premises. (2) Special exception from the zoning board of appeals: a. Utility structure necessary for the transmission or distribution of service (section 27-1445). (3) Special land use permit from the city council: a. Adult day care facility. b. Child day care facility. c. Home occupation involving any customer contact. d. Home stay bed and breakfast residence. e. Kindergarten. f. Neighborhood recreation club. g. Place of worship. h. Private elementary, middle and high school. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-468), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-814. - Lot width, minimum size, and yard requirements. The following lot width, minimum size, and yard requirements shall apply in the TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development) District: (1) Lot width: Each lot for which application is made for TND district zoning shall have a minimum width of 100 feet on a public street. (2) Minimum lot area: See section 27-808. (3) Minimum yard requirements for individual single-family detached dwelling units within a TND district: a. Front yard: None, except that where dwellings have front entry garages, the front of the garage shall be set back at least 22 feet from the front property line. b. Interior side yards: 7.5 feet on each side. c. Side yard along side street on corner lot: 15 feet. d. Rear yard: 20 feet. (4) Minimum spacing between buildings for TND districts containing attached single-family residences and multifamily dwellings: See section 27-1463. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-469), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-815. - Maximum height of buildings. Maximum height of buildings shall be 40 feet, except where accessory commercial use is provided in the ground floor level of buildings containing multifamily housing units above, then the height of any such building shall not exceed 45 feet. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-470), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-816. - Maximum lot coverage. Lot coverage for each TND district established pursuant to this division shall not exceed 60 percent for the development as a whole. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-471), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-817. - Off-street parking requirements. Off-street parking requirements for uses and structures authorized and permitted in the TND (Traditional Neighborhood Development) District are as follows: (1) Accessory commercial uses: Accessory commercial uses shall provide parking as follows: a. Retail uses: Not more than one space for each 250 square feet of floor space devoted to such use; b. All other permissible accessory commercial uses: Same as required in the NS district; c. Location: No parking space for any accessory commercial use shall be permitted to be located in front of such accessory commercial use. (2) Adult day care facility: Four spaces. (3) Child day care facility: Four spaces. (4) Dwellings: a. Single-family detached: Four spaces per dwelling unit. b. Two-family, three-family, and single-family attached: 1. Less than 1,600 square feet of floor area: Two spaces. 2. 1,600 through 1,999 square feet of floor area: Three spaces. 3. 2,000 square feet or greater: Four spaces. c. Multifamily: 1.75 spaces per unit. (5) Elementary, middle or high school: a. Elementary and middle school: Two spaces for each classroom. b. High school: Five spaces for each classroom. (6) Kindergarten: One space per 200 square feet of floor area. (7) Neighborhood recreation club: One space for each five club members. (8) Personal care home, group: Four spaces. (9) Child caring institution, group: Four spaces. (10) Place of worship: One space for each three seats in the largest assembly room used for public worship, or, where fixed seats are not utilized, one space for each 25 square feet of floor space in the largest assembly room used for public worship. (11) Other uses: One space for each 200 square feet of floor area within the principal structure. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-472), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-818. - Minimum dwelling unit size requirements. The minimum size of each dwelling unit shall be as follows: (1) Single-family dwelling: 1,600 square feet. (2) Multifamily dwellings, as follows: a. One bedroom: 650 square feet, provided, however, that 20 percent of the total units in a multifamily dwelling development of more than one building may have a floor area of not less than 520 square feet. b. Two bedroom: 800 square feet. c. Three or more bedrooms: 1,000 square feet. (3) Two- and three-family dwellings: 1,200 square feet. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-473), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-819. - Phasing of projects. TND development may be phased. Where an applicant desires to phase such development, the schedule for development shall be submitted and is subject to approval as a condition of zoning. In all cases where a project is permitted to be phased, each phase of the project shall contain the required parking spaces, open space, recreation space, landscaping and utilities required for that phase. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-474), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-820. - Final approval of plans. Prior to issuance of any development or building permit for any TND development, the final site plan shall be submitted to and approved by the community development director. Said final plan shall be consistent with that plan approved by the city council. The director is authorized to approve minor changes in any such plan subject to the limitations in section 27-1558. The applicant shall submit the final plan to the community development director in a form which complies with the requirements of chapter 14 as to required form for recording of final plats. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-475), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-821. - Relation of TND regulations to subdivision or other regulations. The TND regulations which are contained within this division shall apply to the application for and regulation of all TND districts. Where there are conflicts between these TND regulations and land subdivision requirements contained in chapter 14 or other regulations within this Code, these TND regulations shall apply. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-476), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-822. - Concurrent variances and special exceptions authorized. In enacting an ordinance designating a parcel of land as TND, the city council may enact a plan which provides for variances and special exceptions from rules applying generally in this chapter, or for variances and special exceptions from the requirements generally applicable in this district. Any such variance or special exception shall be subject to the criteria contained in sections 27-1600, 27-1662 or 16-665 as is applicable. After approval of any such TND development plan by the city council, no action is required by the zoning board of appeals. After approval of the final plan and recording of the approved plan of the development by the community development director, the community development department director shall issue development and building permits in accordance with the approved plan. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-477), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-823. - Recording of final plat by community development director. The community development director shall, after final approval of any development plan for TND, record said final plat with the clerk of the superior court of the county. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-478), 9-23-2014) Secs. 27-824—27-854. - Reserved. DIVISION 23. - NCD (NEIGHBORHOOD CONSERVATION) DISTRICT
Sec. 27-855. - Scope of provisions. The provisions contained within this division are the regulations of the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District. This division establishes the procedures and the criteria that the city council shall utilize in making a decision on any application to amend the official zoning map so as to change any parcel of land to the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District zoning classification. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.0), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-856. - Statement of purpose and intent. The purpose and intent of the city council in establishing the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District is to establish a zoning district classification by which the city may permit a variety in type, design, and arrangement of residential structures and enable the coordination of project characteristics with features of a particular site in a manner consistent with the public health, safety, and general welfare. Appropriate areas for the location of a NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District include existing neighborhoods where the characteristics of traditional neighborhood development communities can be preserved. The NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District is established so as to permit reasonable residential development of vacant properties in the defined neighborhood while at the same time protecting and preserving important features of the natural and built environment and to permit innovative design of new housing. The NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District is further intended to accomplish public objectives as follows: (1) To establish a zoning district classification wherein certain established neighborhoods can be preserved within the city; (2) To prevent these neighborhoods and subdivisions from becoming nonconforming under the terms of this division. Any such established neighborhoods will be allowed to continue to exist and develop further under the general regulations governing their design and development in accordance with any plats or plans previously approved; (3) To ensure that infill development authorized pursuant to these district regulations is compatible with the density and the character of surrounding uses; and (4) To ensure that basic services are available to serve the recreational, educational and social needs of the neighborhood. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.2), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-857. - Procedures. The following requirements shall apply to each application for change of the official zoning map to the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District classification: (1) Procedures (same as article V, division 2 of this chapter). Each application for NCD district classification shall be filed with the planning department and shall be reviewed and public hearings conducted with public notice provided and decisions made as is required for all applications to amend the official zoning map pursuant to article V, division 2, of this chapter. (2) Plans required. In addition to all of the information and materials required as part of any application to amend the official zoning map in article V, division 2, of this chapter, each applicant for NCD classification shall submit a site plan which shall contain the following information: a. Size of each lot proposed. b. Housing types. c. Open space areas to be held in joint ownership, common ownership, or control in perpetuity. d. Location and amount of commercial space. e. Location of existing places of worship. (3) Density. The density of the proposed development shall be as approved by the city council at the time of approval of any such application and shall be consistent with the comprehensive plan provided the density does not exceed eight dwelling units per acre. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.3), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-858. - Additional standards and factors to be considered. The city may approve or may approve with modifications or conditions an application for NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District designation if, in addition to meeting all of the criteria contained in article V, division 2, of this chapter, the applicant meets each of the following standards: (1) That the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District accomplishes, through preservation of existing housing and compatible infill development and redevelopment, a neighborhood that has a greater net benefit to the city than would result from redevelopment under the land subdivision regulations. Net benefit to the city may be demonstrated by one or more of the following factors: a. Preservation of existing housing and permitting construction of infill housing compatible with existing housing in size, appearance and value that results in a community of compact scale and design which encourages pedestrian circulation. b. Preservation of a design in which authorized commercial use (if any) is so located as to be accessible to residents of the community. c. Preservation of existing places of worship within the neighborhood. (2) That the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District results in no greater burden on present and projected public services and utilities than would result from subdivision development and that the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District will be served by adequate facilities including public streets, public fire protection, and public and private utilities. (3) That all public streets serving the development, both existing and proposed, are suitable in design and adequate to carry the anticipated traffic within the proposed project and in the vicinity of the proposed project. (4) That the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District shall be limited to existing neighborhoods with at least 50 percent of the houses constructed prior to and including 1950 according to the county tax records. (5) That a minimum of 50 percent of the lots of record in the proposed NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District have 50 feet or less of frontage as measured along the public street frontage according to the county tax records. (6) That the neighborhood which is proposed to become a NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District is a neighborhood with historical significance. (7) That the neighborhood which is proposed to become a NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District shall have a minimum lot area of not less than ten acres. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.4), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-859. - Principal uses and principal structures. The following are the principal uses of land and structures which are authorized in the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District: (1) Dwelling, single-family attached. (2) Dwelling, single-family detached. (3) Dwelling, three-family. (4) Dwelling, two-family. (5) Dwellings, multifamily. (6) Personal care home, group. (7) Child caring institution, group. (8) Open space and public space. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.5), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-860. - Accessory uses, accessory structures, and other authorized uses. The following are the accessory uses of land and structures which are authorized in the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District: (1) Accessory uses and structures incidental to any authorized use; (2) Recreation facilities including swimming pools, tennis courts, outdoor play areas, bikeways, walking trails, picnic pavilions, clubhouses, and similar recreation facilities designed for and used principally by the residents of the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District; (3) Commercial uses, subject to the following requirements: a. Such use shall be limited to uses which are permissible within the NS district (see division 29 of this article) and shall be located only on a major or minor thoroughfare; b. Commercial use shall not exceed 240 square feet of floor area for each ten dwelling units in the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District, and no individual building shall exceed 10,000 square feet in total floor area; c. Within multifamily development, commercial use may be located in freestanding buildings or in the ground floor level of multifamily dwellings; (4) Signs for commercial use in accordance with chapter 21 and this chapter. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.6), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-861. - Special permits. The following uses are allowed by special permits of the type indicated below: (1) Special administrative permit from the community development department director: a. Home occupation involving no customer contact and no employee other than a person residing on the premises. (2) Special exception from the zoning board of appeals: a. Utility structure necessary for the transmission or distribution of service (section 27-1445). (3) Special land use permit from the city council: a. Adult day care facility. b. Child day care facility. c. Home occupation involving any customer contact. d. Home stay bed and breakfast residence. e. Kindergarten. f. Neighborhood recreation club. g. Places of worship. h. Private elementary, middle and high school. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.7), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-862. - Lot width, minimum size, and yard requirements. Lot width, minimum size, and yard requirements in the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District shall be as follows: (1) Lot width: a. Single-family dwelling: 50 feet of frontage as measured along the public street frontage; b. Two-family dwelling: 85 feet of frontage as measured along the public street frontage; c. Three-family dwelling: 100 feet of frontage as measured along the public street frontage; d. Multifamily dwellings: 100 feet of frontage as measured along the public street frontage. (2) Minimum lot area: a. Single-family dwelling: 5,000 square feet; b. Two-family dwelling: 8,000 square feet; c. Three-family dwelling: 10,000 square feet; d. Multifamily dwellings: Two acres. (3) Minimum yard requirements for single-family, two-family and three-family dwelling units within an NCD district: a. Front yard: Front yards shall be consistent with the front yards of buildings on adjoining properties, but not less than 20 feet. b. Interior side yard setbacks: Interior side yards of buildings shall be consistent with the interior side yard setbacks of buildings on adjoining properties, but not less than five feet. c. Side yard along side street on corner lot: 15 feet. d. Rear yard setbacks: Rear yards of buildings shall be consistent with the rear yards of buildings on adjoining properties, but not less than 20 feet. (4) Minimum yard requirements for multifamily dwellings: a. Front yard: 50 feet. b. Side yard: 20 feet, except that where an NCD lot adjoins any lot zoned or used for a single-family residence along a side lot line, the required yard shall be 50 feet. c. Rear yard: 40 feet, except that where an NCD lot adjoins any lot zoned or used for a single-family residence along a rear lot line, the required yard shall be 50 feet. (5) Minimum yard requirements for any lots or structures used for commercial use in any NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District: a. Lot width: All lots shall have at least 100 feet of frontage as measured along the public street frontage; b. Minimum lot area: 20,000 square feet; c. Minimum setback requirements: 1. Front yard: 50 feet; 2. Side yard along side street on corner lot: 50 feet; 3. Interior side yard setback: 20 feet; 4. Rear yard: 30 feet. (6) Development standards for nonconforming lots: A nonconforming lot may be used for a single-family detached dwelling notwithstanding the failure of the lot to meet minimum lot area or minimum lot width requirements specified in the NCD district provided that all other requirements of this division, including minimum yards, shall be met. Such lots shall be exempt from the minimum lot area and minimum lot width requirements and a building permit may be issued without the need for a variance from the zoning board of appeals subject to the following provisions: a. The lot was a legally created lot of record on the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived and the lot was not created in violation of this division; b. The lot was not part of a series of two or more vacant lots in a single ownership, sharing continuous street frontage, and which are sufficient when taken together to meet the minimum lot area and minimum lot width requirements of this division. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.8), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-863. - Maximum height of buildings. The maximum height of buildings shall be 40 feet, except where commercial use is provided in the ground floor level of buildings containing multifamily housing units above, then the height of such building shall not exceed 45 feet. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.9), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-864. - Maximum lot coverage. The lot coverage of each lot shall not exceed 35 percent. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.10), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-865. - Off-street parking requirements. Off-street parking requirements for uses and structures authorized and permitted in the NCD (Neighborhood Conservation) District are as follows: (1) Commercial uses: Commercial uses shall provide parking as follows: a. Retail uses: Not more than one space for each 250 square feet of floor space devoted to such use; b. All other permissible commercial uses: Same as required in the NS district; c. Location: No parking space for any commercial use shall be permitted to be located in front of such commercial use. (2) Adult day care facility: Four spaces. (3) Child day care facility: Four spaces. (4) Dwellings: a. Single-family, two-family, and three-family dwellings: Two spaces for each unit. b. Multifamily dwellings: 1.75 spaces for each unit. (5) Elementary, middle or high school: a. Elementary and middle school: Two spaces for each classroom. b. High school: Five spaces for each classroom. (6) Kindergarten: One space per 200 square feet of floor area. (7) Neighborhood recreation club: One space for each five club members. (8) Personal care home, group: Four spaces. (9) Child caring institution, group: Four spaces. (10) Place of worship: One space for each three seats in the largest assembly room used for public worship, or, where fixed seats are not utilized, one space for each 25 square feet of floor space in the largest assembly room used for public worship. (11) Other uses: One space for each 200 square feet of floor area within the principal structure. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.11), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-866. - Minimum dwelling unit size requirements. The minimum size of each dwelling unit shall be as follows: (1) Single-family dwelling: 1,000 square feet. (2) Multifamily dwellings, as follows: a. One bedroom: 650 square feet, provided, however, that 20 percent of the total units in a multifamily dwelling development of more than one building may have a floor area of not less than 520 square feet. b. Two bedroom: 800 square feet. c. Three or more bedrooms: 1,000 square feet. (3) Two- and three-family dwellings: 1,000 square feet. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.12), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-867. - Final approval of plans. Prior to issuance of any development or building permit within a NCD district, the application shall be submitted to and approved by the community development director. A final site plan shall be submitted and shall be consistent with that plan approved by the city council. The director is authorized to approve minor changes in any such plan subject to the limitations in section 27-1558. The applicant shall submit the final plan to the community development director in a form which complies with the requirements of chapter 14 as to required form for recording of final plats. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.13), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-868. - Relation of NCD regulations to subdivision or other regulations. The NCD regulations which are contained within this division shall apply to the application for and regulation of all NCD districts. Where there are conflicts between these NCD regulations and land subdivision requirements contained in chapter 14 or other regulations within this Code, these NCD regulations shall apply. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.14), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-869. - Concurrent variances and special exceptions authorized. In enacting an ordinance designating a parcel of land as NCD, the city council may enact a plan which provides for variances and special exceptions from rules applying generally in this chapter, or for variances and special exceptions from the requirements generally applicable in this district. Any such variance or special exception shall be subject to the criteria contained in sections 27-1600, 27-1662 or 16-1665 as is applicable. After approval of any such NCD development plan by the city council, no action is required by the zoning board of appeals. After approval of the final plan and recording of the approved plan of the development by the community development director, the community development department director shall issue development and building permits in accordance with the approved plan. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.15), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-870. - Recording of final plat by community development director. The community development director shall, after final approval of any development plan for NCD, record said final plat with the clerk of the superior court of the county. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-481.16), 9-23-2014) Secs. 27-871—27-888. - Reserved. DIVISION 24. - R-NCD (RESIDENTIAL NEIGHBORHOOD CONSERVATION DISTRICT)
Sec. 27-889. - Scope of provisions. The provisions contained within this division are the regulations of the R-NCD (Residential Neighborhood Conservation District). This division establishes the procedures and the criteria that the city council shall utilize in making a decision on any application to amend the official zoning map so as to change any parcel of land to the R-NCD (Residential Neighborhood Conservation District) zoning classification. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.1), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-890. - Statement of purpose and intent. The city council desires to encourage creative residential planning and development within the city that will preserve unique environmental features and be consistent with the comprehensive plan and other city initiatives and plans that provides greenspace areas and preserves existing natural trees and vegetation. The goals of the R-NCD regulations are: (1) To conserve significant areas of useable greenspace within single-family neighborhoods in the rural and suburban character areas of the comprehensive plan; (2) To provide a residential development that permits flexibility of design in order to promote environmentally sensitive and efficient use of land in compliance with this Code; (3) To promote construction of accessible landscaped walking trails and bike paths both within subdivisions and where possible connected to neighboring communities, business, and facilities to reduce reliance on automobiles; (4) To preserve natural features, specimen trees, historic buildings, archaeological sites and establish a sense of community; (5) To improve water quality and reduce runoff and soil erosion by reducing the total amount of clearing, grading, and paving, within the total area of a development; and (6) To encourage efficient community design that reduces infrastructure maintenance and public service costs borne by the city. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.2), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-891. - Scaled site plan. In addition to all of the information and materials required as part of any application to amend the official zoning map in article V, division 2, of this chapter, each applicant for R-NCD shall submit a scaled and dimensioned site plan which, where applicable, shall contain the following information: (1) Size of each lot proposed to be developed within the district; (2) Housing types (i.e., single-family detached, single-family detached condominium); (3) Amount of land in greenspace areas to be held in joint ownership, common ownership, or control in perpetuity; (4) Connections between greenspaces within the project and to greenspace areas on adjacent properties where possible; (5) Building envelopes for fee simple lots; (6) Building and driveway footprint for each single-family detached condominium; (7) Maximum lot coverage; (8) All streams and water bodies depicting state and city stream buffer limits; (9) Vehicular and pedestrian circulation and connections within the project, and to amenities and features on adjacent property; (10) Above-ground detention areas as an amenity feature; (11) Underground detention facilities; (12) Flood hazard areas, wetlands, springheads, and all environmentally sensitive areas, if any; (13) Access to public sewer; (14) All applicable easements; (15) Amount of land area and nonbuildable areas (i.e., rock outcroppings, steep slopes, and significant archaeological sites); and (16) Tree survey in compliance with chapter 14, article III. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.3), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-892. - Calculation and design of greenspace. The following standards shall govern the calculation and design of greenspace: (1) The allotted greenspace in an R-NC district shall comprise at least 30 percent of the total land area excluding the undevelopable areas as identified in section 27-893(d). No part of any single-family detached residential lot, private street, private drive, or street right-of-way, front yard setback, nor any area utilized for side-to-side building separation except when used for a path or sidewalk connection to greenspace, shall count towards greenspace. (2) For properties ten acres or less, at least 50 percent of the allotted greenspace shall be in an area or areas that each measure a minimum 200 square feet. For properties greater than ten acres, at least 50 percent of the allotted greenspace shall be contiguous and shall be a minimum width of 50 feet. (3) Paths, bike paths and trails do not have to comply with the minimum width requirements set forth in subsection (2) of this section. (4) No impervious surface, except areas used for active recreation, historic buildings or historic sites, and asphalt or concrete bike paths and paths with a maximum width of eight feet may be considered in the greenspace calculation. Paths that require grading must not damage critical root zones of specimen trees. (5) Preserved historic buildings or sites may be included in greenspace if intended to be for the common use and benefit of all residents of the subdivision. (6) All dwelling units shall be provided with safe, convenient access to all greenspaces throughout the development in the form of a pedestrian circulation system consisting of structurally improved pedestrian path and/or sidewalk. Pedestrian path and sidewalk shall be a minimum width of five feet. Pedestrian paths and sidewalks shall be connected so that there are no breaks in the walkable surface of the pedestrian circulation system, except where the path or sidewalk connects to a greenspace. (7) Greenspace shall connect with other greenspace areas and trails on adjacent property where possible. (8) Active recreation areas may be included in greenspace and shall be required in any R-NC district that contains 100 or more units. In an R-NC district that contains between 100 and 200 units, the active recreational area shall be a minimum of one acre in size. In any R-NC district that contains more than 200 units, the active recreation area shall be a minimum of two acres in size or there must be a minimum of two active recreation areas that are each one acre in size. However, no active recreation area may be located within any wetland, stream buffer, or rock outcropping. (9) All greenspaces shall have a minimum of two points of pedestrian access. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.4), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-893. - Development standards and permitted uses. (a) Property within a Residential Neighborhood Conservation District shall have a minimum of seven acres and shall comply with all applicable provisions of this Code, and the city arborist. Specimen trees located outside of the buildable area of a lot shall be preserved subject to the review of the city arborist. Active recreation area, greenspace, stormwater management facilities, trails, bikeways, and paths as approved shall be installed prior to the recording of the conservation subdivision final plat. (b) Greenspace may consist of and be designed for the following uses only: (1) Natural undisturbed areas; (2) Active recreation areas; (3) Community gathering places; (4) Trails and greenways; (5) Bikeways and paths; (6) Asphalt or concrete bikeways and paths with a maximum width of eight feet; (7) Landscaped stormwater management facilities, which are constructed as part of an on-site stormwater mitigation site design feature, and which are graded such that no safety fencing is required; (8) Mature wooded areas; or (9) Specimen trees as defined in chapter 14. (c) There shall be no impervious surfaces within the 75-foot stream buffer except as provided for in subsections (b)(4), (5), and (6) of this section. Such encroachments into the stream buffer shall only be permissible in accordance with variances as required by chapter 14. (d) The following features shall not be included for the purposes of calculating whether a site plan and any subsequent development meets the greenspace requirement: (1) Streams and stream buffers; (2) Wetlands; (3) Rock outcroppings; (4) Steep slopes (steeper than 1:2 slope); (5) Sites of archaeological significance; (6) Floodplains; or (7) Areas intended to be dedicated for right-of-way. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.5), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-894. - Principal uses and structures. The following are the principal uses of land and structures which are authorized in the R-NCD (Residential Neighborhood Conservation District) consistent with the comprehensive plan character areas and comprehensive plan densities: (1) Dwelling, single-family detached. (2) Dwelling, single-family detached condominiums. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.6), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-895. - Accessory uses, buildings and structures. (a) The following are the accessory uses of land and structures which are authorized in the R-NCD: (1) Accessory uses and structures incidental to any authorized use. (2) Recreation facilities including swimming pools, tennis courts, outdoor play areas, bikeways, walking trails, picnic pavilions, clubhouses, and similar recreation facilities designed for and used principally by the residents of the R-NCD. (b) Accessory buildings and structures shall comply with the applicable regulations of section 27-1408. (c) Accessory buildings and structures shall conform to the setbacks required for the primary dwelling unit except swimming pools and pool decks. (d) Swimming pools and pool decks shall maintain a minimum ten-foot setback from the side and rear property line. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.7), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-896. - Special permits. The following uses are allowed by special permits of the type indicated below: (1) Special administrative permit from the community development director and development: a. Home occupation involving no customer contact and no employee other than a person residing on the premises. (2) Special exception from the zoning board of appeals: a. Utility structure necessary for the transmission or distribution of service (section 27-1445). (3) Special land use permit from the city council: a. Adult day care facility. b. Child day care facility. c. Convent or monastery. d. Home occupation involving any customer contact. e. Home stay bed and breakfast residence. f. Kindergarten. g. Places of worship. h. Private elementary, middle and high school. i. Personal care home, group. j. Child caring institution, group. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.8), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-897. - Minimum lot width, minimum lot size, building setback, street width, and private drive width requirements. (a) The following standards shall apply to all single-family detached dwellings located in R-NCD within the suburban character area of the comprehensive plan: (1) Density: A maximum of eight dwelling units per acre on total land area excluding undevelopable areas as identified in section 27-893(d). (2) Lot width: All lots shall have a width of at least 60 feet as measured at the required front building setback line. (3) Minimum lot area: 6,000 square feet, except that each lot on the periphery of a development within property zoned R-NCD that abuts adjacent property zoned and developed as single-family residentially zoned property shall contain a lot area that is at least 80 percent of the minimum lot area required by the adjoining residential zoning. (4) Minimum building setback adjacent to public or private street: a. From major thoroughfares: 30 feet. b. From minor thoroughfares: 30 feet. c. From collector streets: 30 feet. d. From other streets: 20 feet. (5) Interior side building setbacks: 7.5 feet. (6) Rear building setback: 20 feet. (7) Lots on periphery of development: Lots on the periphery of any R-NCD development shall maintain a minimum 20-foot side yard setback from any adjacent parcel located outside of the boundary of such development. (b) The following standards shall apply to single-family detached condominiums located in R-NCD within the suburban character area of the comprehensive plan: (1) Maximum density shall be eight dwelling units per acre on total land area excluding undevelopable areas as identified in section 27-893(d). (2) The setback from peripheral property line shall be a minimum of 20 feet, except that when such peripheral property lines adjoin public or private street, setbacks shall be as required in subsection (a)(4) of this section. (3) The distance between all building structures shall be a minimum of 15 feet. (4) The building setback from a private drive or private street shall be no less than ten feet, except that where a garage door or carport entrance faces the street, the setback shall be no less than 20 feet. The building setback shall be measured from back of curb, or, where a sidewalk is provided, from back of sidewalk. (5) Private drive or private street that are internal to the development shall have minimum travel lane width of 24 feet. Where on-street parking is provided, it shall be provided in the form of a parking lane located between the travel lane and the curb. The minimum width of a parallel parking lane shall be ten feet, measured from the edge of the travel lane to front of curb. (6) Sidewalks shall be provided on both sides of private drive or private street that are internal to the development. Street trees shall be those species that cause minimal interference with underground utilities, subject to approval by the city arborist. (7) Driveways shall be a minimum of 20 feet long, measured from back of curb or, where sidewalks are provided, from the back of sidewalk, in order to prevent vehicular encroachment on areas intended for vehicular or pedestrian circulation. (8) A public access and utility easement, in the form of a joint utility trench, shall be located on each side of the internal private street or internal private drive for electric, gas, telephone, and/or cable television utility, and shall be a minimum width of six feet, five inches. (c) The following standards shall apply to all single-family detached dwellings located in R-NCD within the rural character area of the comprehensive plan: (1) Density: A maximum of four dwelling units per acre on total land area excluding undevelopable areas as identified in section 27-893(d). (2) Lot width: All lots shall have a width of at least 60 feet as measured at the required front building setback line. (3) Minimum lot area: 8,000 square feet, except that each lot on the periphery of a development within property zoned R-NCD that abuts adjacent property zoned and developed as single-family residentially zoned property shall contain a lot area that is at least 80 percent of the minimum lot area required by the adjoining residential zoning. (4) Minimum building setback adjacent to public or private street: a. From major thoroughfares: 45 feet. b. From minor thoroughfares: 35 feet. c. From collector streets: 30 feet. d. From other streets: 30 feet. (5) Interior side building setbacks: 7.5 feet. (6) Rear building setback: 40 feet. (7) Lots on periphery of development: Lots on the periphery of any R-NCD development shall maintain a minimum 20 foot side yard setback from any adjacent parcel located outside of the boundary of such development. (d) The following standards shall apply to single-family detached condominiums located in R-NCD within the rural character area of the comprehensive plan: (1) Maximum density shall be four dwelling units per acre on total land area excluding undevelopable areas as identified in section 27-893(d). (2) The setback from peripheral property line shall be a minimum of 20 feet, except that when such peripheral property lines adjoin public or private street, setbacks shall be as required in subsection (a)(4) of this section. (3) The distance between all building structures shall be a minimum of 15 feet. (4) The building setback from a private drive or private street shall be no less than ten feet, except that where a garage door or carport entrance faces the street, the setback shall be no less than 20 feet. The building setback shall be measured from back of curb, or, where a sidewalk is provided, from back of sidewalk. (5) Private drive or private street that are internal to the development shall have minimum travel lane width of 24 feet. Where on-street parking is provided, it shall be provided in the form of a parking lane located between the travel lane and the curb. The minimum width of a parallel parking lane shall be ten feet, measured from the edge of the travel lane to front of curb. (6) Sidewalks shall be provided on both sides of private drive or private street that are internal to the development. Street trees shall be those species that cause minimal interference with underground utilities, subject to approval by the city arborist. (7) Driveways shall be a minimum of 20 feet long, measured from back of curb or, where sidewalks are provided, from the back of sidewalk, in order to prevent vehicular encroachment on areas intended for vehicular or pedestrian circulation. (8) A public access and utility easement, in the form of a joint utility trench, shall be located on each side of the internal street for electric, gas, telephone, and/or cable television utility, and shall be a minimum width of six feet, five inches. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.9), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-898. - Maximum height of buildings. No building shall exceed a height of 40 feet. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.10), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-899. - Maximum lot coverage. The lot coverage of each lot used for a single-family detached dwelling shall not exceed 50 percent. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.11), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-900. - Ownership, control, and maintenance of required greenspace. (a) Unified control of parcel. Any applicant for development within an R-NCD shall be required to provide a legal mechanism for unified control of the entire parcel to be developed, for review and approval by the city attorney prior to the issuance of any land disturbance or building permit. During the development process, more than one builder may participate in the development of the approved plan so long as each parcel of land remains subject to: (1) Any zoning conditions imposed on the property; (2) Any terms and conditions on the approved preliminary plat; and (3) Terms and conditions associated with any special land use permit or any special administrative permit. (b) Maintenance and protection of land held in common. Any applicant for development within a Residential Neighborhood Conservation District will be required to provide a legal mechanism prior to the issuance of any land disturbance permit, under which all land to be held in common and used for greenspace purposes shall be protected in perpetuity. Such legal mechanism may include deed restrictions, homeowners' associations, common areas held in common ownership or control, or conservation easements held by a land trust meeting the requirements of state law, which ensure in perpetuity each of the following mandatory requirements: (1) That all land held in greenspace shall remain undivided and shall not be subdivided or removed from joint access or benefit in perpetuity; (2) That all subsequent property owners in perpetuity within an R-NCD be placed on notice of this development restriction through the deed records filed with the superior court of the county; (3) That all land held as greenspace will be properly maintained to city standards and that no liability or maintenance responsibilities shall accrue to the city; (4) That a legal mechanism exists for notice of deficiencies in maintenance of the land held as greenspace, correction of these deficiencies, and assessment and liens against the properties for the cost of the correction of these deficiencies by a third party or the city; (5) That the legal mechanism will be created and implemented prior to or at the time of recording the final plat and the sale of any individual properties within the conservation district; (6) That all requirements of the legal mechanism chosen by the applicant and approved by the city attorney shall be specified on the final plat to be recorded with the clerk of the superior court of the county. (c) Homeowners' association. When a homeowners' association is used as the legal mechanism to comply with the requirements of this section, the applicant for any land disturbance permit, in addition to meeting all of said requirements, shall provide for all of the following: (1) That all owners have equal access and right of use to all greenspace and that mandatory and automatic membership in the homeowners' association is a requirement of dwelling-unit ownership for all homeowners and their successors; (2) A fair and uniform method of assessment and collection/payment for dues, maintenance and related costs; (3) That the homeowners' association shall have lien authority to ensure the collection of dues from all members; (4) Perpetual and continued maintenance and liability by the homeowners' association of land held as greenspace; and (5) That all required covenants, declarations, and restrictions shall be filed with the clerk of the superior court of the county. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.12), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-901. - Off-street parking requirements. Off-street parking requirements for uses and structures authorized and permitted in the R-NCD (Residential Neighborhood Conservation District) are as follows: (1) Detached single-family dwelling: Three spaces. (2) Detached, single-family condominium dwelling: Three spaces. (3) Personal care home, group: Four spaces. (4) Child caring institution, group: Four spaces. (5) Adult day care facility: Three spaces. (6) Child day care facility: Three spaces. (7) Convent or monastery: One space for each 200 square feet of floor area within the principal structure. (8) Neighborhood recreation club: One space for each five club members but in no case less than ten spaces. (9) Place of worship: One space for each three seats in the largest assembly room used for public worship, or, where fixed seats are not utilized, one space for each 25 square feet of floor space in the largest assembly room used for public worship. (10) Private elementary, middle and high school: a. Elementary and middle school: Two spaces for each classroom. b. High school: Five spaces for each classroom. (11) Other uses: One space for each 200 square feet of floor area within the principal structure. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.13), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-902. - Relation of R-NCD regulations to subdivision or other regulations. The R-NCD regulations which are contained within this division shall apply to the application for and regulation of all R-NCD districts. Where there are conflicts between these R-NCD regulations and land subdivision requirements contained in chapter 14 or other regulations within this Code, these R-NCD regulations shall apply. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-482.14), 9-23-2014) Secs. 27-903—27-921. - Reserved. DIVISION 25. - O-I (OFFICE-INSTITUTION) DISTRICT
Sec. 27-922. - Scope of provisions. The provisions contained within this section are the regulations of the O-I (Office-Institution) District. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-486), 9-23-2014; Ord. No. 2015-06-09, § I(27-486), 6-16-2015; Ord. No. RZ-2017-12-04 , § 1, 12-12-2017) Sec. 27-923. - Statement of purpose and intent. The purpose and intent of the city council in establishing the O-I (Office-Institution) District is as follows: (1) To provide convenient areas within the city for the location of office, institutional uses and limited related retail business and service activities, which are necessary for the residents and business and professional practitioners in buildings of high character in attractive surroundings; (2) To provide locations for the development of cultural, recreational, educational and health service facilities for the city. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-487), 9-23-2014; Ord. No. 2015-06-09, § I(27-487), 6-16-2015; Ord. No. RZ-2017-12-04 , § 1, 12-12-2017) Sec. 27-924. - Principal uses and structures. The following principal uses of land and structures shall be authorized in the O-I (Office-Institution) District: (1) Child day care center and kindergarten. (2) Community facilities as follows: a. Cemetery, columbarium, or mausoleum. b. Cultural facilities. c. Golf course and clubhouse, private. d. Neighborhood recreation center or swimming pool. e. Noncommercial club or lodge. f. Private park. (3) Educational uses as follows: a. Colleges and universities. b. Vocational school. c. Private elementary, middle and high school. d.
