The purpose and intent of the city council in establishing the OCR (Office-Commercial-Residential) District is as follows: (1) To provide for economic development within the city through redevelopment of parcels of land which have been used in the past for commercial and light industrial uses but which have become obsolete and now offer an opportunity for establishing new mixed-use developments of medium intensity which consist of a combination of office, commercial, and residential uses; (2) To promote redevelopment and new development in an environment which is pedestrian-oriented and which provides job opportunities and shopping facilities within the same complex in which multifamily housing is located and thereby reduces dependence on the automobile; and (3) To encourage the conversion of vacant commercial and industrial buildings into residential dwelling units. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-537), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1026. - Principal uses and structures. The following principal uses of land and structures shall be authorized in the OCR (Office-Commercial-Residential) District: (1) Animal hospital, veterinary clinic, pet supply store, animal grooming shop, and boarding and breeding kennel. (2) Art gallery and art supply store. (3) Bank, credit union and other similar financial institution. (4) Child day care center and kindergarten. (5) Convent and monastery. (6) Educational uses as follows: a. Private elementary, middle and high school. b. Specialized nondegree school. (7) Lodging uses, as follows: a. Hotels, when located within a mixed-use development encompassing a minimum of ten acres of land area. (8) Movie theater, bowling alley, and other recreational facilities where such activities are wholly enclosed within a building. (9) Office uses as follows: a. Accounting office. b. Engineering and architectural office. c. Building and construction contractor. d. Financial services office. e. Insurance office. f. Legal office. g. Medical office. h. Real estate office. i. Wholesale sales office. (10) Place of worship. (11) Restaurant. (12) Retail sales as follows, but not including sexually oriented businesses: a. Apparel and accessories store. b. Book, greeting card, and stationery store. c. Camera and photographic supply store. d. Computer and computer software store. e. Convenience store. f. Farm and garden supply store. g. Florist. h. Food stores including bakeries. i. Furniture, home furnishings and equipment store. j. General merchandise store. k. Gift, novelty, and souvenir store. l. Hardware store. m. Hobby, toy and game store. n. Jewelry store. o. Liquor store, including retail liquor store as accessory use to hotels, motels, and high-rise office buildings. p. Music and musical equipment store. q. News dealers and newsstand. r. Office supplies and equipment store. s. Pharmacies and drugstore. t. Quick copy printing store. u. Radio, television and consumer electronics store. v. Specialty store. w. Sporting goods and bicycle sale. x. Variety store. y. Video tape sales and rental store. (13) Services, medical and health, as follows: a. Health service clinic. b. Medical and dental laboratory. c. Offices of health service practitioners. d. Pharmacy. (14) Services, personal, as follows: a. Barbershop, beauty shop, and similar personal service establishment. b. Coin-operated laundry and dry-cleaning store. c. Laundry and dry-cleaning establishment and pickup station. d. Linen and diaper service, garment pressing, alteration and repair. e. Photographic studio. (15) Services, repair, as follows: a. Home appliance repair and service. b. Jewelry repair service. c. Radio, television and similar home appliance repair service. d. Shoe repair store. (16) Shopping center. (17) Tennis center, club and facilities. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-538), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1027. - Accessory uses and structures. The following accessory uses of land and structures shall be authorized in the OCR (Office-Commercial-Residential) District: (1) Parking lots and parking garages. (2) Signs are allowed in accordance with the provisions of chapter 21 and this chapter. (3) Neighborhood recreation centers or swimming pools. (4) Dwellings as follows: a. Single-family, two-family, or three-family dwellings. b. Multifamily dwellings. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-539), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1028. - Special permits. The following uses and structures shall be authorized only by permits of the type indicated: (1) Special administrative permit from the community development department director: a. Home occupation involving no customer contact and no employee other than a person residing on the premises. b. Temporary outdoor social, religious, entertainment or recreation activity where the time period does not exceed 14 days' duration, adequate parking is provided on the site, and where the same lot or any portion thereof is so used for no more than one such 14-day time period within any calendar year. (2) Special exception permit from the zoning board of appeals: a. Utility structure necessary for the transmission or distribution of service (section 27-1445). b. Temporary outdoor social, religious, entertainment or recreation activity where the time period does not exceed 14 days' duration, adequate parking is provided on the site, and where the same lot or any portion thereof is so used for no more than one such 14-day time period within any calendar year. (3) Special land use permit from the city council: a. Building exceeding two stories in height. b. Late-night establishments. c. Nightclubs. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-540), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1029. - Lot width; lot area; setbacks. The following requirements shall apply to all lots and structures in the OCR (Office-Commercial-Residential) District: (1) Lot width and area: All lots shall have at least 100 feet of frontage as measured along the public street frontage. (2) Minimum lot area: Two acres. (3) Minimum setback requirements: a. From public street: 1. Front yard: 50 feet. 2. Side yard: 20 feet. b. Rear yard: 40 feet. (4) Development controls: Multifamily dwellings may be developed at a density not exceeding 30 dwelling units per acre and the combined floor area ratio for any development shall not exceed 1.50. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-541), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1030. - Transitional buffer zone requirement. Where a lot in the OCR (Office-Commercial-Residential) District adjoins the boundary of any property which is zoned for any R classification, RM classification, MHP classification, or TND classification, a transitional buffer zone not less than 50 feet in width shall be provided and maintained in a natural state. Said transitional buffer zone shall not be paved and shall not be used for parking, loading, storage or any other use, except where necessary to grade or modify a portion of the transitional buffer zone for the installation of utilities necessitated by the development. Water detention ponds shall not be located within transitional buffer zones. No trees, other than dead or diseased trees, shall be removed from said transitional buffer zone, but additional trees and plant material may be added to the transitional buffer zone. In addition, a screening fence not less than six feet in height shall be erected and maintained either along the property line or within the transitional buffer zone separating the use from the adjoining residential use. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-542), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1031. - Height of buildings and structures. The maximum height of any building or structure shall not exceed two stories and 35 feet with the exception of single family residential which may not exceed 40 feet. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-543), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1032. - Floor area of dwelling. The minimum floor area of each dwelling unit shall be as follows: (1) One-bedroom: 650 square feet. (2) Two-bedroom: 800 square feet. (3) Three- or more bedroom: 1,000 square feet. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-544), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1033. - Lot coverage. The lot coverage of each lot shall not exceed 80 percent. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-545), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1034. - Off-street parking requirement. Off-street parking requirements for uses and structures authorized and permitted in the OCR (Office-Commercial-Residential) District are as follows: (1) Child day care center and kindergarten: One space for each 200 square feet of floor area. (2) Convent or monastery: One space for each 200 square feet of floor area within the principal structure. (3) Dwellings, multifamily: 1.75 spaces for each dwelling unit. (4) Food stores: One space for each 100 square feet of floor space. (5) Late-night establishment: One space for each 75 square feet of floor area, but not less than ten spaces. (6) Nightclub: One space for each 75 square feet of floor area, but not less than ten spaces. (7) Offices and clinics: One space for each 250 square feet of floor area. (8) Place of worship: One space for each three seats in the largest assembly room utilized for public worship, or, where fixed seats are not utilized, one space for each 25 square feet of floor area in the largest assembly room used for public worship. (9) Private swimming pool, neighborhood recreation center, or similar use: One space for each five members but no less than 20 spaces except that golf courses shall provide a minimum of 20 spaces for each nine holes. (10) Recreational facilities: a. Without fixed seating: One space for each 200 square feet of floor area. b. With fixed seating: One space for each three seats. (11) Restaurant: One space for each 75 square feet of floor area, but not less than ten spaces. (12) Retail uses, personal service uses, and other commercial and general business uses, but not including food stores: Four spaces for each 1,000 square feet of floor area. (13) Schools, commercial vocational: Ten spaces for each classroom. (14) Shopping center: Four spaces for each 1,000 square feet of floor area. (15) Theaters and other places of assembly: One space for each three seats in the main auditorium, or, where fixed seats are not utilized, one space for each 25 square feet of floor space in the largest assembly room utilized for seating. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-546), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1035. - Landscaping requirement for parking lots. See section 27-1429 for landscaping requirements for parking lots. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-638), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1192. - Accessory uses and structures. (2) Signs in accordance with the provisions of chapter 21 and this chapter. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-639), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1193. - Special permits. The following uses and structures shall be authorized only by permits of the type indicated: (1) Special administrative permit from the community development department director: a. Telecommunications tower or antenna, subject to requirements of section 27-1454. b. Art shows, carnival rides and special events of community interest (section 27-1424(1)). c. Rodeos, horse shows, carnivals, athletic events and community fairs (section 27-1424(2)). d. Temporary outdoor social, religious, entertainment or recreation activity where the time period does not exceed 14 days' duration, adequate parking is provided on the site, and where the same lot or any portion thereof is so used for no more than one such 14-day time period within any calendar year. (2) Special exception permit from the zoning board of appeals: None. (3) Special land use permit from the city council: a. Automobile wrecking yard or junk yard. b. Biomedical waste disposal facility, disposal facility, landfill, materials recovery center, solid waste disposal facility, solid waste landfill, private industry solid waste disposal facility, recovered materials processing facility, solid waste handling facility, solid waste thermal treatment technology facility, and disposal facility for hazardous and/or toxic materials including radioactive materials. c. Crematory. d. Explosive manufacture or storage. e. Industrial or business service activities which utilize, manufacture, or process radioactive materials which emit or could emit radioactive levels of 1,000 curies or more and are licensed by the radiological health division of the state department of human resources. f. Intermodal freight terminal, bus or rail freight or passenger terminal, or truck terminal. g. Manufacturing operations not housed within a building. h. Mines and mining operations, quarries, asphalt plants, gravel pits, and sand pits. i. Petroleum refining. j. Railroad car classification yards and team truck yard. k. Railroad classification and repair yard. l. Smelting of metal ores or drop forge industry. m. Storage yard for damaged or confiscated automobiles. n. Temporary outdoor sales, seasonal. o. Truck stop. p. Utility generation facilities. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-640), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1194. - Lot width; lot area; setbacks. The following requirements shall apply to all lots and structures in the M-2 (Industrial) District: (1) Lot width: All lots shall have at least 150 feet of frontage as measured along the public street frontage. (2) Minimum lot area: Two acres for all heavy industrial uses and two acres for all uses permitted by special land use permit; one acre minimum lot size for all other uses. (3) Minimum setback requirements: a. From public street: 1. Front yard: 75 feet. 2. Side yard: 20 feet, except where transitional buffer zone is required. b. Rear yard: 30 feet, except where transitional buffer area is required. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-641), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1195. - Transitional buffer zone requirement. Where a lot in the M-2 (Industrial) District adjoins the boundary of any property which is zoned for any R classification, RM classification, MHP classification, or TND classification, a transitional buffer zone not less than 100 feet in width shall be provided and maintained in a natural state. Said transitional buffer zone shall not be paved and shall not be used for parking, loading, storage or any other use, except where necessary to grade or modify a portion of the transitional buffer zone for the installation of utilities necessitated by the development. Water detention ponds shall not be located within transitional buffer zones. No trees, other than dead or diseased trees, shall be removed from said transitional buffer zone, but additional trees and plant material may be added to the transitional buffer zone. In addition, a screening fence not less than six feet in height shall be erected and maintained either along the property line or within the transitional buffer zone separating the use from the adjoining residential use. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-642), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1196. - Lot coverage. The lot coverage of each lot shall not exceed 80 percent. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-643), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1197. - Height of buildings and structures. No building or structure shall exceed five stories in height. Buildings exceeding five stories in height shall be permitted only upon approval of a special land use permit by the city council. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-644), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1198. - Off-street parking requirement. Off-street parking requirements for uses and structures authorized and permitted in the M-2 (Industrial) District are as follows: (1) Ambulance service, delivery service and other similar services: One parking space for each vehicle plus one additional space for each two administrative or service employees. (2) Funeral home, and other places of assembly: One space for each three seats in the main auditorium, or, where fixed seats are not utilized, one space for each 25 square feet of floor space in the largest assembly room utilized for seating. (3) Automobile repair garage: One space for each 150 square feet of floor space. (4) Heavy and light industrial, manufacturing, and commercial establishments not involving retail sales: One space for each 2,000 square feet of floor area. (5) Offices: One space for each 250 square feet of floor area. (6) Place of worship: One space for each three seats in the main auditorium, or, where fixed seats are not utilized, one space for each 25 square feet of floor space in the largest assembly room utilized for public worship. (7) Public swimming pool, golf course, neighborhood recreation center, or similar use: 20 spaces except that an 18-hole golf course shall have 40 spaces. (8) Private swimming pool, golf course, neighborhood recreation center, or similar use: One space for each five members but no less than 20 spaces except that golf courses shall provide a minimum of 20 spaces for each nine holes. (9) Recreational facilities: a. Without fixed seating: One space for each 200 square feet of floor area; b. With fixed seating: One space for each three seats. (10) Retail uses-incidental, personal service uses, and other commercial and general business uses: 5.5 spaces for each 1,000 square feet of floor area. (11) Temporary outdoor social, religious, entertainment or recreation activity or flea market: One space for each 100 square feet of space used for such activity. (12) Vocational school: Ten spaces for each classroom. (13) Wholesale or jobbing establishments and similar uses: One space for each 200 square feet of floor area devoted to sales or display plus one space for each 2,000 square feet of gross storage area. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-645), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1199. - Landscaping requirement for parking lots. See section 27-1429 for landscaping requirements for parking lots. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-647), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1200. - Signs. Signs are allowed in accordance with the provisions of chapter 21 and this chapter. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-648), 9-23-2014) Secs. 27-1201—27-1218. - Reserved. DIVISION 34. - PC-1 (PEDESTRIAN COMMUNITY) DISTRICT
Sec. 27-1219. - Scope of provisions. The provisions within this division regulate the PC-1 (Pedestrian Community) District. This division establishes the procedures and criteria to use when amending the official zoning map to accommodate PC-1 district zoning classifications. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.1), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1220. - Statement of purpose and intent. The purpose and intent of PC-1 district regulations is to encourage the development of comprehensively planned, pedestrian-oriented, and human-scaled places. The PC-1 district is to permit the flexible and compatible arrangement of residential, commercial, office, institutional, and civic uses, while preserving the significant and valuable features of the natural and artificial environment. The development of a PC-1 district should achieve the following public objectives: (1) To maintain harmony of scale, intensity, and design with surrounding development; (2) To provide for a variety of housing types and styles within a residential component; (3) To facilitate easy and pedestrian-friendly access to compatible and neighboring commercial, civic, recreational, and institutional uses; (4) To design and arrange structures, buildings, streets and open spaces to create an inviting, walkable, human-scale environment; (5) To incorporate the significant and valuable environmental, historic, and archeological features of the zoning district into design of the pedestrian community; (6) To provide the efficient and effective use of land within the pedestrian community; (7) To strengthen the diversity and sense of residential harmony within the pedestrian community; (8) To provide for connectivity of streets and communities and reduce the dependence on automobile uses by increasing the ease of movement and opportunities for alternative modes of travel; and (9) To encourage a proportional relationship of surrounding buildings with respect to the general spacing of structures, building mass and scale, and street frontage by using techniques to achieve compatibility, such as: a. Use of building silhouette: Pitch and scale of rooflines; b. Use of additional facade detail: Proportion of facade elements, doorways, projections and insets; window scale and pattern; creation of strong shadow lines as decorative elements; c. Use of unified setbacks from property lines; d. Use of landscaping to unify buildings and define space; and e. Use of compatible building materials. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.2), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1221. - General standards and procedures. (a) Unified ownership and control. Applicants for rezoning to the PC-1 district shall include the written identification of the owner of the property subject to the rezoning and shall include the legal entity or individual who will exercise control of the land development process. More than one developer may participate in the development of a parcel within a PC-1 district, subject to all the terms and conditions of approved development plans for the entire PC-1 district. (b) Phasing. All stages of a proposed multiple-phasing of a PC-1 district land development and construction must be identified in the initial PC-1 district rezoning application. Each stage and phase of the PC-1 district land development and must meet the requirements of this chapter and division so that the city council has all of the information and detailed plans required by this section to approve all phases of the development at the time the initial zoning ordinance amendment is sought by the applicant. Major changes, as defined in section 27-1558, to the phases of a land development and construction shall require an application for an amendment to the zoning map, review by the planning commission, and the approval by the city council. (c) Plan application requirements. In addition to requirements of an application to amend the official zoning map (article V, division 2, of this chapter), each application for rezoning to the PC-1 district shall meet the applicable provisions of chapter 14 and of this chapter. In addition, each application for the PC-1 district shall include the following: (1) Ten copies of a site plan drawn to a designated scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet, certified by a professional engineer or land surveyor licensed by the state, presented on a sheet having a maximum size of 24 inches by 36 inches, and one 8.5-inch by 11-inch reduction of the plan. If presented on more than one sheet, match lines shall clearly indicate where the several sheets join. Such plan shall contain the following information: a. Boundaries of the entire property proposed to be included in the PC-1 district development, with bearings and distances of the perimeter property lines; b. Scale and north arrow, with north, to the extent feasible, oriented to the top of the plat and on all supporting graphics; c. Location, size and dimensions in length and width of all landscape areas, transitional buffers, and open space; d. Existing topography with a maximum contour interval of five feet and a statement indicating whether it is an air survey or field run; e. Delineation of any floodplain designated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, United States Geological Survey, the city, or the county; f. The delineation of any jurisdictional wetlands as defined by section 404 of the Federal Clean Water Act; g. Approximate delineation of any significant historic or archeological feature, grave, object or structure marking a place of burial if known, and a statement indicating how the proposed development will impact it; h. A delineation of all existing structures and whether they will be retained or demolished; i. Location of all proposed uses, lots, buildings, building types and building entrances; j. Height and setback of all buildings and structures; k. Areas and development density for each type of proposed use; l. Location, size, and number of all on-street and off-street parking spaces, including a shared parking analysis, if shared parking is proposed; m. Identification of site access points and layout, width of right-of-way and paved sections of all internal streets; n. Conceptual plans for drainage with approximate location and estimated size of all proposed stormwater management facilities and a statement as to the type of facility proposed; o. Development density and lot sizes for each type of use; p. Areas to be held in joint ownership, common ownership or control; q. Identification of site access points and layout, width of right-of-way and paved sections of all internal streets; r. Location of proposed sidewalks and bicycle facilities trails, recreation areas, parks, and other public or community uses, facilities, or structures on the site; s. A conceptual layout of building designs including elevations showing architectural details of proposed buildings, exterior materials, all of which shall demonstrate that the proposed design is in compliance with all of the requirements of the PC-1 district regulations; t. Conceptual layout of utilities and location of all existing or proposed utility easements having a width of ten feet or more; u. Standard details of signs, sidewalks, streetlights, driveways, medians, curbs and gutters, landscaped areas, fencing, grating, street furniture, bicycle lanes, streets, alleys, and other details demonstrating compliance with the PC-1 district regulations; and v. Seal and signature of professional preparing the plan. (2) A written statement explaining how the proposed PC-1 district development will meet the standards of this division, including the objectives of section 27-1220. If not previously included on the plan required by this section, the written statement shall also include the type of PC subdistrict requested, the number of acres in each land use, the number of dwelling units by type, the gross residential density, the commercial density, the common open space acreage, the anticipated number, type and size of recreational facilities and other public amenities, and the legal mechanism for protecting and maintaining common open space. (3) A multimodal access plan, prepared at a scale not greater than one inch equals 100 feet, to demonstrate a unified plan of continuous access to and between all structures in the proposed development and adjacent properties. The multimodal access plan shall cover the entire proposed development along with public rights of way of adjoining streets and any other property lying between the subject property and the nearest public streets on all sides. Connections to available transportation modes, such as driveways, sidewalks, and bike paths shall be shown along adjacent streets and those entering adjoining properties. Safe and convenient pedestrian pathways shall be provided from sidewalks along streets to each structure entrance, including pedestrian access routes across parking lots and between adjacent buildings within the same development. Where an existing or planned public transportation station or stop is within 1,250 feet from the nearest boundary of the subject property, the access plan shall show how pedestrians may safely travel from such station or stop to the subject property. Where an existing or planned bike path is located within 1,500 feet from the nearest boundary of the subject property, the access plan shall show how safe, continuous and convenient bicycle access shall be provided to the subject property. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.3), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1222. - Accessory uses, buildings, and structures. Accessory uses and structures incidental to any authorized use, as defined in section 27-1408, are authorized. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.4), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1223. - Special permits. If not specifically allowed as a permitted use in the applicable PC-1 subdistrict, the following uses may be authorized by special permits of the type indicated: (1) Special administrative permit from the community development department director: a. Home occupation involving no customer contact and no employee other than a person residing on the premises. (2) Special exception from the zoning board of appeals: a. Utility structure necessary for transmission or distribution of service in compliance with the requirements of section 27-1445. (3) Special land use permit from the city council, subject to the applicable criteria of this chapter: a. Adult day care facility. b. Child day care facility. c. Home stay bed and breakfast residence. d. Kindergarten. e. Place of worship. f. Private elementary, middle or high school. g. Telecommunications towers. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.5), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1224. - Lot area and yard requirements. (a) Minimum lot area, width, and coverage for authorized structures in the PC-1 district shall be as follows: (1) Single-family detached dwelling: a. Minimum lot area: 4,500 square feet. b. Minimum lot width: 50 feet. c. Maximum lot coverage: 55 percent of the individual lot. (2) Single-family attached dwelling: a. Minimum lot area: 3,250 square feet. b. Minimum lot width: 25 feet. c. Maximum lot coverage: 80 percent of the individual lot. (3) Two-family dwelling: a. Minimum lot area: 5,500 square feet. b. Minimum lot width: 60 feet. c. Maximum lot coverage: 55 percent of the individual lot. (4) Multifamily dwelling: a. Minimum lot area: 21,780 square feet. b. Minimum lot width: 100 feet. c. Maximum lot coverage: 65 percent of the individual lot. (5) Commercial/office/civic building: a. Minimum lot area: 3,500 square feet. b. Minimum lot width: 25 feet. c. Maximum lot coverage: 80 percent of the individual lot. (b) Yard requirements: (1) Single-family detached dwelling on a new street: a. Front yard: Shall be no less than ten feet and no more than 25 feet. Where dwellings have front entry garages, the front of the garage shall be set back at least 12 feet from the front yard line. b. Minimum interior side yard: 7.5 feet on each side. c. Minimum side yard along side street on corner lot: 15 feet. d. Minimum rear yard: 20 feet. (2) Single-family attached dwelling on a new street: a. Front yard: Shall be no less than ten feet and no more than 20 feet. b. Minimum side yard: 15 feet on each side. c. Minimum rear yard: 15 feet. (3) Two-family dwelling on a new street: a. Front yard: Shall be no less than ten feet and no more than 25 feet. Where dwellings have front entry garages, the front of the garage shall be set back at least 22 feet from the front property line. b. Minimum interior side yards: 7.5 feet on each side. c. Minimum side yard along side street on corner lot: 15 feet. d. Minimum rear yard: 20 feet. (4) Multifamily dwelling on a new street: a. Front yard: Shall be no less than ten feet and no more than 20 feet. b. Minimum side yard: 15 feet on each side. c. Minimum rear yard: 15 feet. (5) Nonresidential buildings on a new street: a. Front yard: Shall be a minimum of zero feet and a maximum of 15 feet. (6) Residential dwellings on existing streets: New residential structures on existing streets shall match the front yard setbacks of existing structures on adjoining properties, as described in this subsection. When a lot is located on a block where 60 percent or more of the lots on the same block have residential structures, and where there are existing buildings fronting on the same street and within the same zoning district within 75 feet of the side lot lines of such new residential structure, the front yard setbacks of the new residential structure shall be the average of front yard setbacks of existing residential structures on the lots within 75 feet of the side lot lines of the lot for the new residential structure. If the lot is unable to meet said averaging due to a lack of the required adjacent residential development, then the yard requirements of this subsection (b) as applicable to new streets shall apply. (7) Nonresidential buildings on existing streets: New nonresidential structures on existing streets shall match the front yard setbacks of existing structures on adjoining properties as described in this subsection. When a lot is located within a block where 60 percent or more of the lots within said block have nonresidential development, and where there are existing structures fronting on the same street and within the same zoning district within 75 feet of the side lot lines of such new nonresidential structures, the front yard setbacks generally shall be the average of front yard setbacks of nonresidential structures on lots within 100 feet of the side lot lines of the lot. If the lot is unable to meet said averaging, then the yard requirements of this subsection (b), as applicable to new streets, shall apply. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.6), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1225. - Transitional buffer zone requirements. Where a lot on the external boundary of a PC-1 district is used for nonresidential purposes and adjoins the boundary of any property outside the district that is zoned for any R zoning classification, RM zoning classification, MHP zoning classification, or TND zoning classification, a transitional buffer zone of not less than 50 feet in width shall be provided and maintained in a natural state or so as to maintain an effective visual screen. Said transitional buffer zone shall not be paved or otherwise covered with non-pervious surfaces and shall not be used for parking, loading, storage or any other use, except that portions of the transitional buffer zone may be utilized for installation of utilities when necessitated by the development, and when the applicant shows that the utilities cannot be located outside of the transitional buffer zone. Water detention ponds shall not be located within the transitional buffer zones. No trees, other than dead or diseased trees, shall be removed from said transitional buffer zone, but additional trees and plant material may be added to the transitional buffer zone. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.7), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1226. - Design requirements. Design requirements in the PC-1 district shall be as follows: (1) The front facades of all principal residential and non-residential structures shall be oriented to a public street and sidewalk. (2) The front facades of non-residential structures shall not be oriented toward a parking lot. (3) Non-residential structures shall use doorways, windows, and other openings in the facade of the building to break up the mass of each building. (4) Non-residential structures shall provide fenestration for a minimum of 75 percent of the length of the building frontage along the sidewalk, beginning at a point not more than three feet above the public sidewalk and for a height not less than ten feet above the sidewalk. (5) Non-residential structures shall not exceed a maximum continuous length of ten feet of facade without fenestration. (6) New residential structures and new nonresidential structures shall maintain the architectural character of the places, districts, sites, buildings, structures, objects, or works of art, or historic properties or districts designated, in accordance with the provisions of chapter 13.5. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.8), 9-23-2014; Ordrz. No. 2016-01-01, § II, 1-12-2016 ) Sec. 27-1227. - Streets. (a) All streets within the PC-1 district shall be public streets. Private streets will not be allowed. Streets shall comply with the requirements of public streets found in chapter 14 and other applicable sections of this Code. (b) Streets shall be designed to create an interconnected system of grid-patterned roads, modified only to accommodate topographical conditions. (c) All sides of a residential street in the PC-1 district shall contain nine-foot-wide sidewalks, consisting of a four-foot-wide street tree planting zone measured from the back of the curb and a five-foot-wide pedestrian zone. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.9), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1228. - Maintenance of common land. (a) In an application for the PC-1 district zoning designation, each applicant shall provide the proposed legal mechanism in which all land held in common and used for open space, common open space or greenspace purposes shall be protected in perpetuity. The legal mechanisms may include deed restrictions, homeowner associations, common areas held in common ownership or control, or any other legal creation, and shall be reviewed and approved by the community development department as meeting each of the following mandatory requirements: (1) That all land held in common shall remain undivided and undeveloped, in perpetuity; (2) That all subsequent property owners of property within the parcel and development are placed on notice of this development restriction through the deed records of the superior court of the county; (3) That all land held in common will be properly maintained and insured with no liability or maintenance responsibilities accruing to the city; (4) That a legal mechanism exists for notice of deficiencies in maintenance of the land held in common, correction of these deficiencies, and assessment and liens against the properties for the costs of the correction of these deficiencies by a third party or the city; (5) That the legal mechanism be created and implemented prior to the sale of any individual properties within the PC-1 district parcel; and (6) That all requirements of the legal mechanism chosen by the applicant and approved by the city attorney be specified on the final plat and recorded with the clerk of the superior court of the county. (b) When an applicant for a PC-1 district zoning designation chooses to utilize a homeowners' association in order to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section, the applicant, in addition to meeting all of said requirements, shall provide for all of the following: (1) Mandatory and automatic membership in the homeowners' association as a requirement of dwelling unit and real property ownership; (2) All residential owners shall have equal access and right of use to all common and shared facilities; (3) A fair and uniform method of assessment for dues, maintenance and related costs; (4) Where appropriate, party wall maintenance and restoration in the event of damage or destruction; (5) Perpetual and continued maintenance of land held in common and liability through the use of liens or other means in the case of default; and (6) That all required covenants, declarations and restrictions be filed with the clerk of the superior court of the county. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.10), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1229. - Off-street parking. (a) Off-street parking requirements for uses and structures are authorized and permitted, as follows: (1) Adult day care facility: Four spaces. (2) Child day care facility: Four spaces. (3) Dwellings: a. Single-family detached: Two spaces. b. Single-family attached: Two spaces. c. Multifamily: One space for every dwelling unit and 0.5 parking space for each bedroom. (4) Elementary, middle or high school: a. Elementary, middle school: Two spaces for each classroom. b. High school: Five spaces for each classroom. (5) Kindergarten: One space per 200 square feet of floor area. (6) Neighborhood recreation club: One space for each five members, but no less than 20 spaces. (7) Late-night establishment: One space for each 75 square feet of floor area, but not less than ten spaces. (8) Nightclub: One space for each 75 square feet of floor area, but not less than ten spaces. (9) Place of worship: One space for each five seats in the largest assembly room used for public worship or, where fixed seats are not used, one space for each 50 square feet of floor space in the largest assembly room used for public worship. (10) Other uses: One parking space for every 300 square feet of gross building area. (b) Shared parking is encouraged and may result in permitted reductions of off-street parking requirements. Parking facilities within the parcel may be shared if multiple uses cooperatively establish and operate parking facilities and if these uses generate parking demands primarily when the remaining uses are not in operation, so that the above-stated off-street parking requirements for each use are met or exceeded during said use's operational hours. Applicants may make application to the community development director for authorization for shared parking. Applicants shall include proof of a written formal shared parking agreement between all applicants. (c) All parking lots for commercial, office, civic, institutional, or public uses shall be located at the rear or side of the building. If located at the side, the lot shall be screened through the use of solid street walls or landscaping to reduce visual impact. Street walls shall be a minimum of five feet in height and a maximum of six feet in height and shall provide a minimum of 80 percent opacity. Street walls shall not consist of chain link fencing with plastic inserts. Acceptable materials for street walls will include, but not be limited to, wood slats, brick or pierced brick garden walls. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.11), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1230. - Signs. All PC-1 districts shall comply with the sign requirements of chapter 21. Additionally, ground signs shall be monument style signs with a base and framework made of brick or stone. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.12), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1231. - Relation of PC-1 district regulations to subdivision or other regulations. To the extent the subdivision or other regulations impose additional requirements beyond those contained in this division, such additional requirements also shall apply. Where there are conflicts between the PC-1 district regulations and land subdivision requirements contained in chapter 14 or other regulations within this Code, the PC-1 district regulations shall control. If the city council approves an application to rezone property to a PC-1 district zoning classification and such approval complies with all the applicable requirements of the PC-1 district regulations, then the approved plan shall be considered and treated as a preliminary plat, as defined by chapter 14. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.13), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1232. - Development standards for PC-1 district. The PC-1 district should form a smooth transition between existing residential areas and higher density residential and commercial uses. In addition to sections 27-1219 through 27-1231, the following standards and criteria shall apply to PC-1 districts. (1) PC-1 districts shall meet each of the following criteria: a. The parcel shall be located within areas zoned and developed as low to medium density single-family residential neighborhoods; b. The parcel shall contain one or more of the following environmentally sensitive site features that warrant protection through the use of a clustering design within an overall lower density setting: wetlands; scenic views; forested areas; surface water; historic or archeological features; unique topography; and c. Development of the parcel would support a long-term strategy of protecting the character of existing neighborhoods and providing for compatible growth consistent with the comprehensive plan. (2) The following principal uses and structures shall be authorized in the PC-1 district: a. Residential uses as follows: 1. Dwelling, single-family detached. 2. Personal care home, group. 3. Child caring institution, group. 4. Dwelling, single-family attached. 5. Dwelling, two-family. b. Commercial and office uses authorized in section 27-1056. c. Open space and common open space. d. Community meeting and recreation facilities, including, but not limited to, swimming pools, tennis courts, outdoor play areas, bikeways, walking trails, picnic pavilions, and clubhouses. e. Accessory dwelling units. Accessory dwelling units shall meet all of the following standards: 1. The accessory dwelling unit shall be on the same lot as the principal dwelling unit to which it is accessory. 2. The accessory dwelling unit may be attached to, or detached from, the principal dwelling unit. 3. The accessory dwelling unit shall be subject to the setbacks and height requirements of the underlying zoning district for the principal dwelling unit, provided that a detached accessory dwelling unit shall not be closer than ten feet to a side or rear lot line. 4. A detached accessory dwelling unit shall be located to the rear of the principal dwelling unit. 5. The accessory dwelling unit shall conform to all applicable standards for building, plumbing, electrical, mechanical, fire, health, and other applicable codes for residential units. 6. Each lot shall contain no more than one accessory dwelling unit. 7. The property owner, who shall include titleholders and contract purchasers, must occupy either the principal dwelling unit or the accessory dwelling unit as their residence. 8. The accessory dwelling unit shall be a minimum size of 300 square feet and a maximum size of 600 square feet. 9. The accessory dwelling unit shall be designed so that the appearance of the building remains similar to that of a single-family residence. 10. The maximum height of the accessory dwelling unit shall be 20 feet or the height of the primary structure, whichever is less. (3) Within the PC-1 district, the number of residential dwelling units and the amount of nonresidential development (excluding open spaces and common open spaces) shall be determined as follows: a. Residential density on any parcel designated PC-1 district, with single-family dwelling units, shall not exceed five dwelling units per acre, excluding accessory dwelling units. b. Residential density on any parcel designated PC-1 district with single-family attached and two-family dwelling units shall not exceed eight dwelling units per acre. c. Single-family attached and two-family dwelling units shall not exceed 20 percent of total housing units within the entire parcel. d. Nonresidential uses shall not exceed 20 percent of the total acreage of entire parcel. e. Nonresidential construction shall not commence unless certificates of occupancy have been issued for 30 percent of the planned residential development. (4) Building height shall not exceed 40 feet; however, any building combining ground-level retail with office above shall not exceed 45 feet in building height. (5) The minimum size of each dwelling unit shall be as follows: a. Single-family detached or attached: 1,200 square feet excluding authorized accessory units. b. Two- and three-family dwellings: 1,200 square feet per dwelling unit. (6) Individual nonresidential uses shall not exceed 15,000 square feet of the building footprint. (7) Open space and common open space shall comply with all of the following requirements: a. A minimum of 20 percent of the PC-1 district parcel shall be open space. b. A minimum common open space shall be a contiguous one acre and this one acre of common open space shall count towards the 20 percent requirement set forth in subsection (7)a of this section. c. A minimum of 80 percent of the required open space shall be in the form of common open space and shall include, but shall not be limited to, one or more of the following forms: 1. Designated historic and archeological sites. 2. Environmental corridors. 3. Protected natural areas and conservation buffers. 4. Parks and squares. 5. Streams, ponds and other water bodies. 6. Active recreation facilities. 7. Passive recreation pathways (other than sidewalks) and linear parks. 8. Plazas or pedestrian promenades. d. No more than 20 percent of common open space shall consist of impervious surface areas. e. Seventy-five percent of all housing units on the parcel shall be within 1,320 linear feet of common open space measured in a straight line from the closest edge of the housing unit to the closest edge of the common open space. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-649.14), 9-23-2014) Secs. 27-1233—27-1252. - Reserved. DIVISION 35. - PC-2 (PEDESTRIAN COMMUNITY) DISTRICT
Sec. 27-1253. - Scope of provisions. The provisions within this division regulate the PC-2 (Pedestrian Community) District. This division establishes the procedures and criteria to use when amending the official zoning map to accommodate PC-2 district zoning classifications. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.1), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1254. - Statement of purpose and intent. The purpose and intent of PC-2 district regulations are to encourage the development of comprehensively planned, pedestrian-oriented, and human-scaled places. The PC-2 district is to permit the flexible and compatible arrangement of residential, commercial, office, institutional, and civic uses, while preserving the significant and valuable features of the natural and artificial environment. The development of a PC-2 district should achieve the following public objectives: (1) To maintain harmony of scale, intensity, and design with surrounding development; (2) To provide for a variety of housing types and styles within a residential component; (3) To facilitate easy and pedestrian-friendly access to compatible and neighboring commercial, civic, recreational, and institutional uses; (4) To design and arrange structures, buildings, streets and open spaces to create an inviting, walkable, human-scale environment; (5) To incorporate the significant and valuable environmental, historic, and archeological features of the zoning district into design of the pedestrian community; (6) To provide the efficient and effective use of land within the pedestrian community; (7) To strengthen the diversity and sense of residential harmony within the pedestrian community; (8) To provide for connectivity of streets and communities and reduce the dependence on automobile uses by increasing the ease of movement and opportunities for alternative modes of travel; and (9) To encourage a proportional relationship of surrounding buildings with respect to the general spacing of structures, building mass and scale, and street frontage by using techniques to achieve compatibility, such as: a. Use of building silhouette: Pitch and scale of rooflines; b. Use of additional facade detail: Proportion of facade elements, doorways, projections and insets; window scale and pattern; creation of strong shadow lines as decorative elements; c. Use of unified setbacks from property lines; d. Use of landscaping to unify buildings and define space; and e. Use of compatible building materials. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.2), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1255. - General standards and procedures. (a) Unified ownership and control. Applicants for rezoning to the PC-2 district shall include the written identification of the owner of the property subject to the rezoning and shall include the legal entity or individual who will exercise control of the land development process. More than one developer may participate in the development of a parcel within a PC-2 district, subject to all the terms and conditions of approved development plans for the entire PC-2 district. (b) Phasing. All stages of a proposed multiple-phasing of a PC-2 district land development and construction must be identified in the initial PC-2 district rezoning application. Each stage and phase of the PC-2 district land development and must meet the requirements of this chapter and division so that the city council has all of the information and detailed plans required by this section to approve all phases of the development at the time the initial zoning ordinance amendment is sought by the applicant. Major changes, as defined in section 27-1558, to the phases of a land development and construction shall require an application for an amendment to the zoning ordinance, review by the planning commission, and the approval by the city council. (c) Plan application requirements. In addition to requirements of an application to amend the official zoning map (article V, division 2, of this chapter), each application for rezoning to the PC-2 district shall meet the applicable provisions of chapter 14 and of this chapter. In addition, each application for the PC-2 district shall include the following: (1) Ten copies of a site plan drawn to a designated scale of not less than one inch equals 100 feet, certified by a professional engineer or land surveyor licensed by the state, presented on a sheet having a maximum size of 24 inches by 36 inches, and one 8.5-inch by 11-inch reduction of the plan. If presented on more than one sheet, match lines shall clearly indicate where the several sheets join. Such plan shall contain the following information: a. Boundaries of the entire property proposed to be included in the PC-2 district development, with bearings and distances of the perimeter property lines; b. Scale and north arrow, with north, to the extent feasible, oriented to the top of the plat and on all supporting graphics; c. Location, size and dimensions in length and width of all landscape areas, transitional buffers, and open space; d. Existing topography with a maximum contour interval of five feet and a statement indicating whether it is an air survey or field run; e. Delineation of any floodplain designated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency, United States Geological Survey, the city, or the county; f. The delineation of any jurisdictional wetlands as defined by section 404 of the Federal Clean Water Act; g. Approximate delineation of any significant historic or archeological feature, grave, object or structure marking a place of burial if known, and a statement indicating how the proposed development will impact it; h. A delineation of all existing structures and whether they will be retained or demolished; i. Location of all proposed uses, lots, buildings, building types and building entrances; j. Height and setback of all buildings and structures; k. Areas and development density for each type of proposed use; l. Location, size, and number of all on-street and off-street parking spaces, including a shared parking analysis, if shared parking is proposed; m. Identification of site access points and layout, width of right-of-way and paved sections of all internal streets; n. Conceptual plans for drainage with approximate location and estimated size of all proposed stormwater management facilities and a statement as to the type of facility proposed; o. Development density and lot sizes for each type of use; p. Areas to be held in joint ownership, common ownership or control; q. Identification of site access points and layout, width of right-of-way and paved sections of all internal streets; r. Location of proposed sidewalks and bicycle facilities trails, recreation areas, parks, and other public or community uses, facilities, or structures on the site; s. A conceptual layout of building designs including elevations showing architectural details of proposed buildings, exterior materials, all of which shall demonstrate that the proposed design is in compliance with all of the requirements of the PC-2 district regulations; t. Conceptual layout of utilities and location of all existing or proposed utility easements having a width of ten feet or more; u. Standard details of signs, sidewalks, streetlights, driveways, medians, curbs and gutters, landscaped areas, fencing, grating, street furniture, bicycle lanes, streets, alleys, and other details demonstrating compliance with the PC-2 district regulations; and v. Seal and signature of professional preparing the plan. (2) A written statement explaining how the proposed PC-2 district development will meet the standards of this division, including the objectives of section 27-1254. If not previously included on the plan required by this section, the written statement shall also include the type of PC subdistrict requested, the number of acres in each land use, the number of dwelling units by type, the gross residential density, the commercial density, the common open space acreage, the anticipated number, type and size of recreational facilities and other public amenities, and the legal mechanism for protecting and maintaining common open space. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.3), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1256. - Accessory uses, buildings, and structures. Accessory uses and structures incidental to any authorized use, as defined in section 27-1408, are authorized. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.4), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1257. - Special permits. If not specifically allowed as a permitted use in the applicable PC-2 subdistrict, the following uses may be authorized by special permits of the type indicated: (1) Special administrative permit from the community development department director: a. Home occupation involving no customer contact and no employee other than a person residing on the premises. (2) Special exception from the zoning board of appeals: a. Utility structure necessary for transmission or distribution of service in compliance with the requirements of section 27-1445. (3) Special land use permit from the city council, subject to the applicable criteria of this chapter: a. Adult day care facility. b. Child day care facility. c. Home stay bed and breakfast residence. d. Kindergarten. e. Place of worship. f. Private elementary, middle or high school. g. Telecommunications towers. h. Late-night establishment. i. Nightclub. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.5), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1258. - Lot area and yard requirements. (a) Minimum lot area, width, and coverage for authorized structures in the PC-2 district shall be as follows: (1) Single-family detached dwelling: a. Minimum lot area: 4,500 square feet. b. Minimum lot width: 50 feet. c. Maximum lot coverage: 55 percent of the individual lot. (2) Single-family attached dwelling: a. Minimum lot area: 3,250 square feet. b. Minimum lot width: 25 feet. c. Maximum lot coverage: 80 percent of the individual lot. (3) Two-family dwelling: a. Minimum lot area: 5,500 square feet. b. Minimum lot width: 60 feet. c. Maximum lot coverage: 55 percent of the individual lot. (4) Multifamily dwelling: a. Minimum lot area: 21,780 square feet. b. Minimum lot width: 100 feet. c. Maximum lot coverage: 65 percent of the individual lot. (5) Commercial/office/civic building: a. Minimum lot area: 3,500 square feet. b. Minimum lot width: 25 feet. c. Maximum lot coverage: 80 percent of the individual lot. (b) Yard requirements: (1) Single-family detached dwelling on a new street: a. Front yard: Shall be no less than ten feet and no more than 25 feet. Where dwellings have front entry garages, the front of the garage shall be set back at least 12 feet from the front yard line. b. Minimum interior side yard: 7.5 feet on each side. c. Minimum side yard along side street on corner lot: 15 feet. d. Minimum rear yard: 20 feet. (2) Single-family attached dwelling on a new street: a. Front yard: Shall be no less than ten feet and no more than 20 feet. b. Minimum side yard: 15 feet on each side. c. Minimum rear yard: 15 feet. (3) Two-family dwelling on a new street: a. Front yard: Shall be no less than ten feet and no more than 25 feet. Where dwellings have front entry garages, the front of the garage shall be set back at least 22 feet from the front property line. b. Minimum interior side yards: 7.5 feet on each side. c. Minimum side yard along side street on corner lot: 15 feet. d. Minimum rear yard: 20 feet. (4) Multifamily dwelling on a new street: a. Front yard: Shall be no less than ten feet and no more than 20 feet. b. Minimum side yard: 15 feet on each side. c. Minimum rear yard: 15 feet. (5) Nonresidential buildings on a new street: a. Front yard: Shall be a minimum of zero feet and a maximum of 15 feet. (6) Residential dwellings on existing streets: New residential structures on existing streets shall match the front yard setbacks of existing structures on adjoining properties, as described in this subsection. When a lot is located on a block where 60 percent or more of the lots on the same block have residential structures, and where there are existing buildings fronting on the same street and within the same zoning district within 75 feet of the side lot lines of such new residential structure, the front yard setbacks of the new residential structure shall be the average of front yard setbacks of existing residential structures on the lots within 75 feet of the side lot lines of the lot for the new residential structure. If the lot is unable to meet said averaging due to a lack of the required adjacent residential development, then the yard requirements of this subsection (b), as applicable to new streets, shall apply. (7) Nonresidential buildings on existing streets: New nonresidential structures on existing streets shall match the front yard setbacks of existing structures on adjoining properties as described in this subsection. When a lot is located within a block where 60 percent or more of the lots within said block have nonresidential development, and where there are existing structures fronting on the same street and within the same zoning district within 75 feet of the side lot lines of such new nonresidential structures, the front yard setbacks generally shall be the average of front yard setbacks of nonresidential structures on lots within 100 feet of the side lot lines of the lot. If the lot is unable to meet said averaging, then the yard requirements of this subsection (b), as applicable to new streets, shall apply. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.6), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1259. - Transitional buffer zone requirements. Where a lot on the external boundary of a PC-2 district is used for non residential purposes and adjoins the boundary of any property outside the district that is zoned for any R zoning classification, RM zoning classification, MHP zoning classification, or TND zoning classification, a transitional buffer zone of not less than 50 feet in width shall be provided and maintained in a natural state or so as to maintain an effective visual screen. Said transitional buffer zone shall not be paved or otherwise covered with non-pervious surfaces and shall not be used for parking, loading, storage or any other use, except that portions of the transitional buffer zone may be utilized for installation of utilities when necessitated by the development, and when the applicant shows that the utilities cannot be located outside of the transitional buffer zone. Water detention ponds shall not be located within the transitional buffer zones. No trees, other than dead or diseased trees, shall be removed from said transitional buffer zone, but additional trees and plant material may be added to the transitional buffer zone. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.7), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1260. - Design requirements. Design requirements in the PC-2 district shall be as follows: (1) The front facades of all principal residential and non-residential structures shall be oriented to a public street and sidewalk. (2) The front facades of non-residential structures shall not be oriented toward a parking lot. (3) Non-residential structures shall use doorways, windows, and other openings in the facade of the building to break up the mass of each building. (4) Non-residential structures shall provide fenestration for a minimum of 75 percent of the length of the building frontage along the sidewalk, beginning at a point not more than three feet above the public sidewalk and for a height not less than ten feet above the sidewalk. (5) Non-residential structures shall not exceed a maximum continuous length of ten feet of facade without fenestration. (6) New residential structures and new nonresidential structures shall maintain the architectural character of the places, districts, sites, buildings, structures, objects, or works of art, or historic properties or districts designated, in accordance with the provisions of chapter 13.5. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.8), 9-23-2014; Ordrz. No. 2016-01-01, § II, 1-12-2016 ) Sec. 27-1261. - Streets. (a) All streets within the PC-2 district shall be public streets. Private streets will not be allowed. Streets shall comply with the requirements of public streets found in chapter 14 and other applicable sections of this Code. (b) Streets shall be designed to create an interconnected system of grid-patterned roads, modified only to accommodate topographical conditions. (c) All sides of a residential street in the PC-2 district shall contain nine-foot-wide sidewalks, consisting of a four-foot-wide street tree planting zone measured from the back of the curb and a five-foot-wide pedestrian zone. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.9), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1262. - Maintenance of common land. (a) In an application for the PC-2 district zoning designation, each applicant shall provide the proposed legal mechanism in which all land held in common and used for open space, common open space or greenspace purposes shall be protected in perpetuity. The legal mechanisms may include deed restrictions, homeowner associations, common areas held in common ownership or control, or any other legal creation, and shall be reviewed and approved by the community development department as meeting each of the following mandatory requirements: (1) That all land held in common shall remain undivided and undeveloped, in perpetuity; (2) That all subsequent property owners of property within the parcel and development are placed on notice of this development restriction through the deed records of the superior court of the county; (3) That all land held in common will be properly maintained and insured with no liability or maintenance responsibilities accruing to the city; (4) That a legal mechanism exists for notice of deficiencies in maintenance of the land held in common, correction of these deficiencies, and assessment and liens against the properties for the costs of the correction of these deficiencies by a third party or the city; (5) That the legal mechanism be created and implemented prior to the sale of any individual properties within the PC-2 district parcel; and (6) That all requirements of the legal mechanism chosen by the applicant and approved by the city attorney be specified on the final plat and recorded with the clerk of the superior court of the county. (b) When an applicant for a PC-2 district zoning designation chooses to utilize a homeowners' association in order to comply with the requirements of subsection (a) of this section, the applicant, in addition to meeting all of said requirements, shall provide for all of the following: (1) Mandatory and automatic membership in the homeowners' association as a requirement of dwelling unit and real property ownership; (2) All residential owners shall have equal access and right of use to all common and shared facilities; (3) A fair and uniform method of assessment for dues, maintenance and related costs; (4) Where appropriate, party wall maintenance and restoration in the event of damage or destruction; (5) Perpetual and continued maintenance of land held in common and liability through the use of liens or other means in the case of default; and (6) That all required covenants, declarations and restrictions be filed with the clerk of the superior court of the county. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.10), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1263. - Off-street parking. (a) Off-street parking requirements for uses and structures are authorized and permitted, as follows: (1) Adult day care facility: Four spaces. (2) Child day care facility: Four spaces. (3) Dwellings: a. Single-family detached: Two spaces. b. Single-family attached: Two spaces. c. Multifamily: One space for every dwelling unit and 0.5 parking space for each bedroom. (4) Elementary, middle or high school: a. Elementary, middle school: Two spaces for each classroom. b. High school: Five spaces for each classroom. (5) Kindergarten: One space per 200 square feet of floor area. (6) Neighborhood recreation club: One space for each five members, but no less than 20 spaces. (7) Late-night establishment: One space for each 75 square feet of floor area, but not less than ten spaces. (8) Nightclub: One space for each 75 square feet of floor area, but not less than ten spaces. (9) Place of worship: One space for each five seats in the largest assembly room used for public worship or where fixed seats are not used, one space for each 50 square feet of floor space in the largest assembly room used for public worship. (10) Other uses: One parking space for every 300 square feet of gross building area. (b) Shared parking is encouraged and may result in permitted reductions of off-street parking requirements. Parking facilities within the parcel may be shared if multiple uses cooperatively establish and operate parking facilities and if these uses generate parking demands primarily when the remaining uses are not in operation, so that the above-stated off-street parking requirements for each use are met or exceeded during said use's operational hours. Applicants may make application to the community development director for authorization for shared parking. Applicants shall include proof of a written formal shared parking agreement between all applicants. (c) All parking lots for commercial, office, civic, institutional, or public uses shall be located at the rear or side of the building. If located at the side, the lot shall be screened through the use of solid street walls or landscaping to reduce visual impact. Street walls shall be a minimum of five feet in height and a maximum of six feet in height and shall provide a minimum of 80 percent opacity. Street walls shall not consist of chain link fencing with plastic inserts. Acceptable materials for street walls will include, but not be limited to, wood slats, brick or pierced brick garden walls. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.11), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1264. - Signs. All PC-2 districts shall comply with the sign requirements of chapter 21. Additionally, ground signs shall be monument-style signs with a base and framework made of brick or stone. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.12), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1265. - Relation of PC-2 district regulations to subdivision or other regulations. To the extent the subdivision or other regulations impose additional requirements beyond those contained in this division, such additional requirements also shall apply. Where there are conflicts between the PC-2 district regulations and land subdivision requirements contained in chapter 14 or other regulations within this Code, the PC-2 district regulations shall control. If the city council approves an application to rezone property to a PC-2 district zoning classification and such approval complies with all the applicable requirements of the PC-2 district regulations, then the approved plan shall be considered and treated as a preliminary plat, as defined by chapter 14. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.13), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1266. - Development standards for PC-2 district. The PC-2 district should reinforce or extend existing commercial centers and mixed-use neighborhoods and promote the redesign and revitalization of underused commercial areas. In addition to sections 27-1253 through 27-1265, the following standards and criteria shall apply to all PC-2 districts: (1) PC-2 districts shall meet each of the following criteria: a. Adjacent to or set within an existing commercial or employment node within the city. b. Extend or reinforce an existing, surrounding mix of higher density housing, commercial or office uses. c. Support the revitalization of underused commercial areas, including stand-alone shopping centers or a combination of strip development and single-use buildings containing offices, multifamily housing, and service and retail uses. d. Have sufficient transportation access (an ability to connect easily to the existing road network and transit system) and infrastructure capacity to support a dense mix of residential and nonresidential activity. e. Support a desired long-term growth strategy to concentrate multiple activities within areas of the city designated by the comprehensive plan for denser residential or commercial uses or mixed-use or other areas as deemed appropriate by the city. (2) The following principal uses and structures shall be authorized in the PC-2 district: a. All uses authorized in the NS (Neighborhood Shopping) District. b. All uses authorized in C-1 (Local Commercial) District except those uses identified in section 27-1084(1), (3)a, c, d, e, f, (10), (13), (16), and (19), as amended. c. All uses authorized in the OI (Office-Institution) District except those uses identified in section 27-925(2)a, c, f, (3), (5), (6), (8), (9)a, (10) and section 27-926(1), as amended. d. All uses authorized in C-2 (General Commercial) District except those uses identified in section 27-1125(1), (3)a, b, d, e, f, g, h, (6)a, b, (9), (15), (17), (19)i. e. Residential uses, as follows: 1. Dwellings, single-family detached. 2. Personal care homes, group. 3. Child caring institutions, group. 4. Dwellings, single-family attached. 5. Dwellings, two-family. 6. Dwellings, multifamily. 7. Accessory dwelling units. 8. Live-work units. f. Accessory dwelling units shall meet all of the following standards: 1. The accessory dwelling unit shall be on the same lot as the principal dwelling unit to which it is accessory. 2. The accessory dwelling unit may be attached to, or detached from, the principal dwelling unit. 3. The accessory dwelling unit shall be subject to the setbacks and height requirements of the underlying zoning district for the principal dwelling unit, provided that a detached accessory dwelling unit shall not be closer than ten feet to a side or rear lot line. 4. A detached accessory dwelling unit shall be located to the rear of the principal dwelling unit. 5. The accessory dwelling unit shall conform to all applicable standards for building, plumbing, electrical, mechanical, fire, health, and other applicable codes for residential units. 6. Each lot shall contain no more than one accessory dwelling unit. 7. The property owner, who shall include titleholders and contract purchasers, must occupy either the principal dwelling unit or the accessory dwelling unit as their residence. 8. The accessory dwelling unit shall be a minimum size of 300 square feet and a maximum size of 600 square feet. 9. The accessory dwelling unit shall be designed so that the appearance of the building remains similar to the architectural character of the principal dwelling unit. 10. The maximum height of the accessory dwelling unit shall be 20 feet or the height of the primary structure, whichever is less. g. Live-work units shall meet all of the following standards: 1. Uses shall be compatible with residential use and shall not produce or create noise, smoke, vibrations, smells, electrical interference, or fire hazards that would unreasonably interfere with residential uses. Permitted uses shall include: (i) Accounting office. (ii) Planning, engineering or architectural office. (iii) Financial services office. (iv) Insurance office. (v) Legal office. (vi) Counseling office. (vii) Real estate office. (viii) Information processing uses. (ix) Tutorial/educational services. (x) Fine arts studios and/or galleries. (xi) Photography studios. (xii) Consulting services. 2. The maximum number of employees on the premises shall be two, in addition to the occupants of the residential space. 3. The unit shall not accommodate more than two customers at a time and shall limit operation to the hours of 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. 4. The minimum size of the live-work unit shall be 1,200 square feet with at least one-third of the unit designated for residential space. 5. The residential space shall be occupied by the owner of record or tenant. h. Open space and common open space. i. Community meeting and recreation facilities, including, but not limited to, swimming pools, tennis courts, outdoor play areas, bikeways, walking trails, picnic pavilions, and clubhouses. (3) The number of residential dwelling units and the amount of nonresidential development (excluding open spaces and common open spaces) shall be determined in PC-2 district as follows: a. Residential density in the PC-2 district shall not exceed 60 dwelling units per acre, excluding accessory dwelling units. b. A minimum of 30 percent of the parcel shall be used for residential uses. c. A minimum of ten percent of the parcel shall be used for nonresidential uses. d. Individual nonresidential uses shall not exceed 50,000 square feet per parcel. The building footprint area for each individual use shall not exceed 25,000 square feet. e. The building height of buildings in the residential component shall not exceed 40 feet, except where buildings combine ground-level retail or office with multifamily housing units in the same building, the height of such building shall not exceed 60 feet. (4) The minimum height of nonresidential buildings shall be 26 feet. (5) No building height shall exceed 60 feet. (6) The minimum size of each dwelling unit shall be as follows: a. Single-family detached or attached: 1,000 square feet excluding authorized accessory units. b. Multifamily dwellings: 1. One bedroom: 650 square feet. 2. Two bedrooms: 800 square feet. 3. Three or more bedrooms: 1,000 square feet. c. Two- and three-family dwellings: 1,200 square feet. (7) Open space and common open space shall comply with all of the following requirements: a. A minimum of ten percent of the PC-2 district parcel shall be open space. b. A minimum of 80 percent of the required open space shall be in the form of common open space and shall include, but shall not be limited to, one or more of the following forms: 1. Environmental corridors. 2. Courtyards. 3. Plazas. 4. Pedestrian walkways. 5. Outdoor seating areas. 6. Child-care outdoor spaces. c. No more than 20 percent of common open space shall consist of impervious surface areas. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-650.14), 9-23-2014) Secs. 27-1267—27-1290. - Reserved. DIVISION 36. - PC-3 (PEDESTRIAN COMMUNITY) DISTRICT
Sec. 27-1291. - Scope of provisions. The provisions within this division regulate the PC-3 (Pedestrian Community) District. This division establishes the procedures and criteria to use when amending the official zoning map to accommodate PC-3 district zoning classifications. (Ord. No. 2014-09-03, § I(27-651.1), 9-23-2014) Sec. 27-1292. - Statement of purpose and intent.
